Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States

yTK_E83Z6XI6LB1TG2jDMQ.text: Came here after waiting for almost 2 hours to get in to Bacchanal... (I'm not sure ANY place is worth waiting that long to eat)  I'm not sure why this place only got 3 star on average. But the service we got was excellent... The food was spectacular!  Everything we ordered was delicious!  And the total of the bill?  Well, it's cheaper than Bacchanal, and we were stuffed.

xrM8X60N-Ti6FoDdtSGCMA.text: In a word: nostalgia.  The food isn't bad, but there are so many great restaurants in Las Vegas that you really shouldn't waste your time on overpriced and mediocre food like Rao's.  If you are from NY and can't get a table there, maybe it will serve some emotional purpose for you.  But take your money and go to Bouchon instead.

xXyq8x9ftU-otIU1BAmOSA.text: Very good food. Very good service. Good drinks. Not cheap, but that's Vegas and Caesar's Palace; worth the money. Our party had the meat balls (house speciality) shrimp, filet and lamb. All well prepared and delicious. Our server - John - was excellent.

t1qHtcmhHtFqClSxSwycjQ.text: Hearing good things about this place from my cuz, a group of us agreed on this Italian joint for dinner.   They had two hostesses. We were left with what with the icier of the two women that led us to our table. Based on her demeanor, one could presume she wasn't in a good mood or didn't want to be there. I think it would have been an insurmountable challenge for her to even crack a smile.  We were seated at a table that was located in a spot that it really didn't belong. The table was located in the room to the left, in the position where a door would be placed.  During the course of the meal, a number of dining parties had to pass right by our table to get to theirs. It would have made more sense to have maybe a table for two or four here in it's place to allow more space to pass through but that's just some food for thought (no pun intended). The place is pretty loud for such a restaurant and the sound carries which is a byproduct of a room with low ceilings and a sitting near the room's entrance/exit.  We tried the famous Traditional Rao's Meatballs.  I would say the meatballs were the highlight portion of the meal. At about the size of an orange and served in two these balls of meat (pork, beef and veal) were bathed in the marinara sauce, tender and cooked immaculately.   On to the main course: the red rose went to the..... Linguine with clams and red sauce. I didn't detect the pepper flakes or white wine. Probably had I gone with the white sauce, certain elements to the dish might have stood out more. I did like how they toss the pasta at the table right before serving. I think it does prevent the sauce and ingredients from falling to the bottom of the plate. It was a solid dish but wouldn't called it spectacular. The red sauce didn't exactly pop with the pasta. Quite frankly I think I could have prepared a dish that could have resulted in similar quality.   The service and waitstaff were spotty with the exception of the water guy. If we were a group of girls, the service would have been a notch or two better. Our waiter got "thirsty" once a party of women were seated a few tables down from us and was more attentive to them.   At least with the dessert I got hooked up with an extra scoop of gelato, courtesy of the favorable mistake on the part of the dessert chef.    Does the food here warrant a return trip from me? Unless it's the meatballs I'd say "naw".  Now some of the attractive women dining here made for an interesting dinner. But that's another story for another day.

photos.caption: Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Linguini with Clams
Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Thanks for the 4 Scoops of Vanilla/Strawberry

FeKcRmode8FGO1e8z5gqWA.text: OMG the food is amazing. We had the Meatballs (Simply Divine). The Ravioli's were almost like dumplings, very good. The penne ala vodka was good. The chicken piccata was a little different, not as lemony as expected.   Service was excellent. Greater waiter.

XBRfwttnXLdsktwP8v4-YQ.text: Rao's is one of those places that costs too much but keeps me coming back often.  In NYC, this restaurant has 10 or so tables and you need to make a reservation about a year in advance!  Here in Las Vegas, it's much more accessible.  And I'm glad it is because there's something incredible about the food!   The service here is hit or miss.  The first time I came years ago, it was flawless.  It felt like you didn't just pay for the food but also for impeccable and attentive service.  That's not to say it's poor now; just that there has not been as much attention to detail in recent visits.    The wine list at Rao's is expansive and the sommelier is always knowledgable and helpful if we're having trouble deciding.    I love, love, love Rao's marinara and arrabiata sauce.  Good sauce is so vital to any italian meal and Rao's is among the best!  I sometimes want a little bit of a kick in my meal and they're usually accommodating by giving me a "toned down" version somewhere in between regular marinara and arrabiata.    You HAVE to try the meatballs.  I don't even like meatballs but these are legendary!  The compliments come with 2 huge meatballs and they're great if you're splitting them as an appetizer or adding them as a side to your meal.  The ravioli purses are amazing!  I love that the servers carefully and delicately transfer your meal on to a plate right at the table in front of you.  The NY cheesecake with fresh berries is simply decadent.  My favorite dessert, however, is the peanut butter tart.  We came most recently for restaurant week and, at $50 for 3 courses, it was a steal!  The usual prices are the only thing that keep me from coming more often and, as it is, I already come every couple of months.  My mouth is already watering thinking of my next meal there!

sKw5_vxBjn3WUVeQy579uA.text: My husband and I have been wanting to try this restaurant and was looking for a special occasion to do so. Father's day was the perfect occasion and we participated in Las Vegas Restaurant week, three square. We were not disappointed we had a great meal, excellent service and a full belly. We did not even get to finish our dessert.

5G2w8P8T9ef1LxIWmsUUtw.text: Ah Rao's. Living in the NYC area we have wondered what the food would be like as the Rao's in the city is hard, if not impossible, to get into. The destination is actually popular as a charity item with a reservation usually going for somewhere on the order of $10,000. Yes, that's a reservation and not the meal which we hear is of low to average cost for something in NYC.  Thus we had to head to Rao's in Las Vegas to see what the food is all about assuming...and hoping...it would be close to the elusive fare closer to our home. One of the dishes in particular that we wanted to try were the meatballs since our high mark on those has become Macaluso's in Miami Beach, FL.  So, how did everything turn out? First, it was fun going to the location. Caesars itself has always been a cut above. I remember from 30 years ago when the buffets were $2.99 at all of the other places and you would go to Caesars and spend the big $7.99 to get something really amazing. Well, at least for my first impression that scale of class still continues as you approach Rao's and see what looks like the facade of the NYC location rebuilt in the middle of the casino on the inside.  Our reservations took us to the back... It started out as a quiet meal but the only downside to the entire experience was an extremely loud table of around 10 guys shouting at each other (describing their volume and not demeanor) for the entire dinner. Oh well... I had a caesar salad -- wow, it was huge! (and good) and a salmon dish for the main entree. The main dish was excellent but what about those meatballs?  Well, I think Macaluso's has a runner in the top competition and the only way to figure out which is best is to do a side by side blind taste test on this one. Instead of trying to actually arrange that somehow I will leave the result for someone else to figure out and simple enjoy the best meatball experience at both places depending on where we are in the country.

AKjfwfTVvlpUTpG5TPaDkw.text: Had dinner here with some out-of-towners.  It was a busy Saturday night on the strip and we made a reservation for 6.   We ordered a variety of things including appetizers, entrees, and dessert.  The appetizers are small and overpriced for being so small.  They were delicious, but clearly overpriced.  I wasn't super impressed with the cocktails either.  The best item on the menu were the meatballs.    I think that's really the big thing with this restaurant.  The food is GREAT.  But very overpriced.    For $30 a pasta, you would think the entrees would be one of a kind.  They are not.  You can have an excellent Italien meal at Nora's (in Las Vegas) for way less!   The only other issue I had was that they didn't do separate checks.  We were with 2 other couples who have a tendency to cheap out on the tip.  We simply wanted separate checks to take care of that issue.  They said they couldn't do it....their loss!

JGKr1kVacfZRPhtkA3wUog.text: What a lovely experience. Howie was our server and he made the evening fabulous for us. The food was delicious, but Howie made the experience for the seven of us. We also called the restaurant ahead of time to provide a surprise birthday cake. The restaurant made a great tasting cake! Loved it. Highly recommend them.

0dOWt558WwBMBLyPcciCyQ.text: If you go order the meat ball appetizer, they are great. I ordered the veal chop Parmesan and it was fantastic.

KTv4pgd4mxhtfHqgPExFGg.text: This is a over due review. I visited bout 10 years ago back when "Bubbles" was the first face you saw and the last one when you left.  It was one of the best experiences of our trip to Vegas that year.  I was out at the pool and was complaining about a meal i had at another hotel, well the owner and bubbles were poolside and requested that we join them at their poolside table.  After a bit of time drinking and talking we were invited to Rao's for dinner that night. As my father and I got ready later that evening, we never could have expected the meal and service we received that night. We walked into the restaurant and Bubbles greeted us, WELCOME MR K. , and MR K. we have your table ready. Long story short, this single gesture by the Rao's family turned a so so trip to Vegas into a truly remember-able experience.      I will be back in Vegas in a couple days and look forward to my reservation that we have already booked, even though "Bubbles" is no longer with us.  RIP Bubbles.    I hope my future review is just as good as my first, because I'm already looking forward to the meatballs, veal parm, and wine.

BVeM_RBnIxVA1leejwCM-w.text: Date night with my very Italian boyfriend. We went in at 9:30 on a Tuesday night and It was mediocre (if that). We ordered the meatballs, penne vodka, clam linguine, a house Chianti, and a vodka soda.  Meatballs: as good as everyone says they are. A must try! I would order more than one plate.  Penne vodka: I'm not Italian so I haven't had the best, but this was nothing special.  Clam linguine: pass x a thousand. Gross. Smelled rotten almost. Taste was even worse. Frank? Our server was ok. Wish he had asked us if we needed anything else or another glass of wine but it was late at night and I understand he wanted to go home. I work in food too. House Chianti was spectacular btw. Order a bottle if you can. All in all, average rating. There are better Italian restaurants out there so I probably won't be back. Not much of a selection either, but it is Italian after all..

aPejTuPFfJ7zbAA0IlYZLw.text: Know going in that Rao's is old old school, old world italian dining. Some knock that, but thats a weak criteria for criticism.  But make no mistake Rao s serves top notch food using top of the line ingredients. Bread basket was money, as was the quality of EVOO and balsamic.  The caprese, beet salad, anti pasto, , penne vodka (pitch perfect al dente) and meatballs were sampled and we re nothing short of extraordinary.  We left stuffed but satisfied and impressed. Subtle, low key, but professional service by Sean.  This isnt cheap but nothing is in Vegas. If you re into Italian, you ll dig Rai 's.  RECOMMENDED.

Wa2UCvWcVS_0DnskwinkAg.text: Dinner at Rao's last night was amazing.  The crazy thing is that I saw the owner, Frank Pellegrino Jr, standing by the wall sipping on some coffee and I walked over and struck up a conversation with him.  I told him I'd seen him on tv a few times.  Frankie is a total class act.  Extremely approachable and grateful.  He thanked me for coming over to talk to him and asked where our party was sitting.  He then added, 'I'd like to buy you all a round.'  He bought us a bottle of wine!    Aside from that really cool experience, we asked Mike, our bartender (really good guy) what he recommended.  "Without a doubt, you have to have our meatballs, our fried mozzarella and the clams."  We ordered one of each and they were really, really good.    We wanted to try a main course and split it and Mike recommended his favorite.  He asked us to order the veal parmesan and it really was a wonderful plate.  The size was big enough to feed two if you order an appetizer, say the meatballs to go with it.      The ambience is very cool.  It's low lit, I saw a bocce ball court in the back, great music and also the photos of the celebrities on the walls are pretty neat, as well.    New York City is pretty far from here and I hear getting a table there can be quite difficult.  So, I'm happy we have a Rao's here in Vegas.  We'll come back for sure.

D7YExl0zOupVd4G_b9jGnw.text: cons: very pricey Pros: the food is just fantastic. their appetizer meatballs and calimariie are freaking awesome. for my main meal was lenguine with clams. fantastic. i would recommend this restaurant. just be prepared to pay a hefty price

FoqVOg1GehAhv4Tcmk1bqQ.text: I still am a fan but removed Rao's from my Las Vegas Rotation only because both our chicken dishes were on the dry side this time.  The service at Rao's is very welcoming and professional. The bread basket is good and the pasta we tried was phenomenal!   Our server did ask about what I thought about the food I did say the sauce was very good.....but she did ask me about the chicken and I was honest and said it was on the dry side. She did offer to me another dish but I didn't take the offer.  I don't eat here often and last time it was very  VERY good.  3.5

nlxY2617eSPTg_Risp-Aow.text: Close but no cigar.  I love the attempt at reproducing old-school NY Italian and ths place comes close to succeeding but doesn't quite make the mark.  Food-wise, the baked clams were nice, but the presentation was weak.  (Think:  throw 5-6 clams on a regular white plate.)  The spaghetti bolognese missed the mark -- nothing spectacular for $25+.  The veal parmigiana was very good (but not quite outstanding) but at $50+, it should come not naked on the plate but perhaps with a bit of pasta and veggies on the side.

8f4KkSC0NUyUlZ_pnjaKAA.text: Good Italian comfort food. Superior service from Johnny Two Scoops. Really good bartender Big Mike Waz. Music??? Freebird during dinner not so compatible.

COqXhd0Fqc0y-afD_uEEtQ.text: Taglioline with peas and ham was absolutely delicious! Great service both at bar and in the dining room. Having dinner with friends, one had the lasagna, the other had the veal, both stated theirs was delicious as well.

dqBdka3lIc0nTZOlURvsHQ.text: A "foodie" friend suggested Rao's ..... and We are soooooooo glad we came here.   There is a special feeling and magic to the restaurant that is warm, romantic, and cozy----- it is a must do in Vegas.     It is a little pricey --- but worth it!  Dinner for two was 230.00. --- We had a cocktail, a bottle of chianti (65.00), meatballs, caprese salad, lemon chicken, after dinner drinks ....and they gave us a free tiramasu for our anniversary --- that was really nice!!!  Great Service.... and Great in so many ways!!!

nLs7F6RMpko40ucS1Vptqw.text: This restaurant was a major disappointment.  Like other Yelpsters I found the food to be very bland and not what I was expecting given its New York reputation and prices.  In my opinion the food is on the level of Olive Garden and below Pasta Pomodoro.  YIKES!  The primary reason we went here was the fairly decent reviews and because we were going to see a show at Caesar's.  After a couple of bad experiences eating at hotel restaurants in Vegas...I'll stick to those that are standalone restaurant businesses for now on (e.g., Maggiano's and Casa Di Amore).

GKon61LLP_k6V89tF9F1aQ.text: Just had dinner last night at Rao's. Not impressed. Service was just OK. We ordered the baked clams. Nothing special Too much breadcrumbs with hardly any flavor. Next was the cold seafood appetizer. Again nothing special. Then we ordered Shrimp  fra diavolo for our dinner.  The shrimp had a fishy smell and the pasta was overcooked and did not have enough sauce. Also the bread basket was cold and did not have good crustly bread. We are locals and hoped it would be a restaurant we we would frequent but we will not be back!!!

qHcIBrdQ49nch72V_8fb_A.text: After viewing reviews and menus of many restaurants in Vegas, I opted to book a reservation at Rao's to celebrate my birthday. I had wanted something more upscale with a menu that is accommodating as I am a vegetarian but my fellow travelers are not.   My reservation had been made for 6:45PM, as nothing was available between 7 and 8 PM. We arrived to the restaurant close to 7, after being held up waiting on transportation. I was nervous that they would cancel the reservation and I'd miss out, but we had no problem when we got to the restaurant.  We were seated at a table in the New York replica room. Our server was Shaun A, who was very attentive and accommodating - he was always quick to refill waters and gave us plenty of time to review menus and enjoy our meal and time together. I enjoyed the ambiance and it did was easy to forget that you were in a busy restaurant as it was not noisy nor did it have a crowded feeling.  I had a caprese salad to start, which had the freshest mozzarella I've been able to experience thus far. I followed it up with the ravioli purses, after seeing many raves. The dish is so flavorful, and it was actually hot - unlike food you'll find at most restaurants today. Upon being brought to the table, a member of my group commented that it was a good portion - it certainly looks that way, but it is deceiving! This little bites are very filling, and sweet. As much as I wanted to continue eating them due to them being good, I was unable to.   Others in my group ordered the meatballs, which received great reviews. One had the house salad, remarking that it was the best salad he had ever eaten (he is no salad connoisseur, but it did appear to have a good mix of flavors). He also had rave reviews about the pork chop he had ordered and the potatoes.   We opted not to order dessert. The menu was very appealing, but none of us could continue eating. I was brought a tiramisu, however, which was phenomenal. I don't eat tiramisu that often, but this one was again full of flavor and topped with a good quality cocoa and one I would order.  Our bill ended up coming out to around $68 per person. We could cut this cost down some on a future visit by sharing entrees as they are very filling. Two in the group ordered meatballs, for example, but could only manage to eat one each and myself and another each consumed about half of our ravioli purses. The restaurant allows for sharing without any hassle, even encouraging it for some items.   I am really happy that I opted to book at Rao's and that it did not disappoint. It will definitely be considered for future visits and recommended to others.

photos.caption: Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tiramisu

Dn7gCjtW-Q_xzY5O1SKipQ.text: Terrible. Had to send everything back and totally mediocre. The marinara sauce tasted like it was out of a can. Spending that kind of money for this was ridiculous

CH9fHHxiox76g68r6W4etw.text: My husband and I were celebrating our anniversary and as a surprise he made reservations here, the service was outstanding the staff was very nice and attentive. We ordered a drink from the bar since our table was not yet ready, I ordered a margarita on the rock its not the best one I have tasted it was more lime juice than anything. We were seated at our table we ordered a Cesar salad and some meatballs they  were very delicious the food came out in a timely manner. I had the lime chicken it was very tasty and juicy my husband had the pork chops and he said it was the best he has had. I definitely recommend this place and will return.

photos.caption: Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork chop
Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lime chicken

hUwm6oK63EpKMEJdFMjiyw.text: This was my third visit to Rao's and it's just as awesome as ever! We had the meatballs for our appetizer, and they were incredible as always! So moist and delicious, they literally melt in your mouth! Then I had the Penne Vodka and it was REALLY good. Perfect taste, perfect portion, perfect consistency. For dessert we split the peanut butter tart and it's to die for! So good I still think about it!  If you love Italian food, this place is not to be missed in Las Vegas. it's a little pricey, but really not bad for the quality and service you get. Run, don't walk!

-uQ_N8Sbih_IC_Jwc77D1Q.text: Had a good solid meal here. Braised veal ribs I had we're very good, large portion that could be shared. Friend had the meat lasagna and commented it was very good.  Overpriced for food quality, but in line with the celebrity themed restaurants in Las Vegas.  The dinning room is setup to look like someone's idea of what the original looks like. Problem is the original is very small. Faux  memorabilia on the walls.

1WnZGCJkpziDTOQPOaUTwg.text: Everything was delicious from Caprese Salad, mussels, linguini with clams and the ginormous meatballs, and last but not the least Tiramiso for dessert - superb!

YItAQhpMB54ZEp79m4K-UA.text: Food was pretty decent, staff was attentive. Disappointed of no active duty military discount, as price was a bit on the expensive side. Portions good.

photos.caption: Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States

BOPTMnqCHcvvdVUtIaaPOQ.text: Oh Rao's I wanted to love you. I buy your sauce at the market and yet. First let me say the staff is fantastic. The bruschetta was yummy and I had a delicious wine that our waiter recommended.   I was excited for the ravioli. I'm talking eat a small breakfast and fruit for lunch excited. I was prepared to eat but all I could taste was garlic. Now I love garlic but I couldn't taste the sweetness in the sauce, the basil, the spinach or even the ricotta. It was straight vampire killing garlic.   My husband's dish was the same and he is a card carrying garlic lover, which is not always fun for me. He even said, "wow that's A LOT of garlic maybe I shouldn't eat all of this." If you like to sweat out your garlic late go for it.

YzHduiolpaoq4oNDUSOquA.text: One of my favorite Italian places to go to. I've been here several times and it doesn't disappoint. Everything comes out flavorful, and they are all large enough portions. And let me just say, best meatball EVER.  Hands down. In every restaurant I go to, I compare the meatballs I order to Rao's meatball. It is amazing. That is all.

_qf9eQLXQoM3KR3d-T2aIw.text: I love Rao's for two things 1. Penne in vodka sauce and 2. their meatballs. If those are the only two items offered to me when I visit, I would not feel like I missed out on anything. I have dined here a few times and each time we go big and try a few more items, but the two dishes that sit close by will always be these two. The al dente penne tosses in the rose cream sauce with bits of ham always brings a smile to my face. I am still a kid that plays with his food. Lacing each individual piece over a prong of the fork and eating them one by one is my way to savor this pasta. The mix of veal, pork, and beef in the meatballs makes them what they are. The size and portion is unheard of. Complaints about leaving hungry should never happen.   The service is fast and friendly. Small talk is relaxed and feels like it is coming from the small mom and pop type of shop. Although Rao's is upscale in every sense of the word, it was not stuffy.   We ended our meal with  a dessert buffet. Nothing stood out as a must have again, but it was nice to try them. The ice cream in the profiteroles was my favorite. Usually, I love tiramisu, but the lady fingers had lost their consistency long ago and turned to mush. The flavor was there.

2kN3WE6NkZNGH7_ilBbxCQ.text: This review is long overdue but hey what can I say I am a busy guy. I came to Vegas for my 35th birthday with my brother and a close friend in October of 2011. When we do Vegas, we always try and go big meaning we do the fancy expensive restaurants that we normally wouldn't ever do at home. I wanted to eat at Rao's for my birthday dinner since I love Italian food and am a mob buff. I read about the history of the original Rao's Restaurant in New York and the traditions they kept and used to authenticate the Las Vegas location. Also I read that at least one of the owners Frank Pellegrino and his son Frank Pellegrino Jr. were there every night. Do some research and you'll see you'll remember Frank Pellegrino from Goodfellas and the Sopranos.  As I mentioned in the above paragraph the Las Vegas Rao's took some of the traditions from their New York location and put them here. When you walk in you see the bar decorated with the Christmas decorations up regardless of what time of year it is. It's a really warm inviting vibe with the Christmas lights and holly especially since I love Christmas. Also the jukebox is blaring music but I have to say they have only good stuff (real music) on the jukebox such as Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, and Louis Prima and I was honored to be able to play some songs and that jukebox. They also have framed photos covering almost every area of the walls of family and celebrities who autographed them.  The food was awesome, real authentic Italian cuisine. I had the Mozzarella Planks for an appetizer, Chicken Parmesan for the main course and a glass of Chianti. The whole meal was delicious and the service was great. Picture an atmosphere where the music is loud, everyone there is enjoying themselves with great food and drink and you got Rao's.  We paid our bill and as we were leaving I noticed the owner Frank Pellegrino Jr. by the bar area. I went up to him and introduced myself and told him it was my first time dining at Rao's and that my party and I loved everything about the whole Rao's experience from the ambience and atmosphere to the food. He was very kind, courteous and receptive and thanked me for coming in and asked if he could buy me and my party a round of drinks at the bar. I was floored by this kind gesture and said I appreciated it but it wasn't necessary and he said he insisted. I called my brother and my friend and they met me back at the bar and I introduced them to Mr. Pellegrino Jr. and we got to chill at the bar with a nice drink after dinner.  Amazing service like this is so rare and hard to find now a days so that's why I take the time to make sure the world knows about it when it happens. Frank Pellegrino Jr. and the Rao's staff are all class acts and they make you feel like part of their family. I will be back for sure next time and I am in Vegas and would give this place 10 stars if I had the option!

BEJoGiXxZQaUdr1Hb01lLg.text: I'm totally giving Rao's five stars because unlike a lot of the reviews I have read I love this place!! I've frequented it while shopping Caesars and honestly have never been dissapointed with the meals nor the service!! My favorite meal here is the tagliatelle pasta with peas and ham. Along with the meatballs. Check it out for great Italian on the strip!!

uYEIdb8DfqooHOHS3F6dQg.text: So delicious! Always. The best meatballs in the house. Warmly lit and cozy atmosphere. If your looking for a classic Italian dining experience away from the casino, but right in the action, go here! Great customer service, as well. Good for a date or business dinner inside. If you want wonderful food and to see the casino, you can sit on the indoor patio. Always consistent. Always delicious.

Tw5I3VHGU7ibBNsvHmpeVA.text: Fantastic, fantastic MEATBALLS!!!!! OMG! The service and atmosphere were wonderful. Very similar feel to an authentic Italian restaurant in NYC. The server was amazing and the food was great. We really liked the down-home feel and warmth to the place.

KGWfgWFVFfrDcvOo60Tn-w.text: When the server spills food on your husbands lap and the manager refuses to comp the check, you're getting reviewed. I even called and tried to speak with the billing department manager but that got me nowhere. I'll be disputing the charge with my bank and never going back. Oh, and you don't garnish a martini with an olive unless it's ordered dirty. You also don't argue with the customer about it. Bartending 101.

D4ROiHg7k-ws-z5x2fhNYA.text: I had a phenomenal experience at Rao's. We came here for a team outing and it was amazing.   First of all, the ambiance is very old school Italian. Low dimmed lights, quiet music ~ definitely a great place for a date. The servings are quite large so it is also great for large groups.   For starters, we had the calamari and the roasted beet salad. The calamari was delicious. It had a light breading with the right amount of crunch. It comes with tartar sauce and marinara sauce. The beet salad was delightful. I'm actually not a big fan of beets, but man these ones were delicious! The pistachios and goat cheese paired well with the arugula and beets was yummy.   We had two pasta dishes: the ravioli purses and their signature penne vodka. The penne vodka was delicious. The sauce was perfect. The ravioli purses was amazing! It's stuffed with pear and ricotta cheese in a butter, sage, and cranberry sauce. I've never had anything that tasted like this before. It was delicious!   For the main entrees we had the lemon chicken, pork chop, meatballs, and shrimp. My personal favorite were the meatballs. I always think the meatballs have a fairly generic taste and I've never been a big fan, but man, these meatballs are amazing! I would recommend hundred percent! The pork chop was also delicious. If you're a fan of pickled peppers, you'd love this. The lemon chicken was very tasty and juicy. The shrimp was also very good.   As far as the desserts, my personal favorite was the tiramisu but the cheesecake and the cannolis were yummy as well.  Service, food, and ambience was definitely five stars all the way.

zABLFf6zZjCHyRKbw3eDDA.text: This place is quite pricy, but of course it was worth it. Had some house wine, but woof, it was a bit pricy, lol. I went with a filet and it was great (from what I remember LOL). All in all, I'll definitely be back. The steak was topped with a great sauce, very unique. Ended up Being over $200, and we were eating at the bar, haha, but it's Vegas. That was only for one meal and a few drinks.   But hey, it was a worthwhile experience.

PETUhxiShWsTPhSC1M9FHg.text: Food is great and authentic. They were able to build the Italian flavors in each dish. We had the Ossobucco and Shrimp Fra Diavolo - switch it to a Penne pasta instead - awesome as our main course and had the meatballs and clams as appetizers.  All 4 dishes were great. Great service as well. We brought our own 2013 Scarecrow Cab and $50 for corkage fee.  I would go back. Ambience is dark and romantic.

J0tB4Gkx8mTi6RZLHhPCeA.text: This is my fourth visit to Raos in Caesar's Palace and I was disappointed.  Alone, I sat at the bar on an empty Monday evening.    I wasn't drinking alcohol but ordered a soft drink and reviewed the menu I'm already familiar with.  I asked the bartender/server if it was possible to order the famous "softball size" meatball with a side (Caesar) salad.  He told me the only Caesar salad was large---too much for me when I was only moderately hungry.  Instead, he suggested the Caprese salad.  The meatball was bland even in the gravy and the Caprese salad was uninspiring.  The bartender/server never checked back with me with only one other customer at the entire bar much less refill my drink.  It was over $35 for mediocre food and worse service.

C-ZArIwL_6KR2I3EfcUQbg.text: The food is really solid. Everything is well seasoned and flavorful. It's overpriced, I think that's undeniable, but if you just want a really tasty meal and don't mind the $$$, it's a great time.

cQ49ZvpILLAhVW8E2QZ_PQ.text: I really don't know what they hype is.  Grant it, this is not the original, that is impossible to get into, but I read an article that read "if you want to eat at Rao's NY, fly to Vegas, it's the same, that even a family member was always at the Vegas location to ensure quality"..    Well, it was disappointing.   This place epitomized to me the old "Vegas food" that was too hyped and just meh.     The ambiance was fine, dark, old school Italian, a the lamps are the Rao's tomato sauce, which all the products are sold everywhere.  There were lots of empty tables on a Thursday night at 8:30 pm.  Meatballs are considered a must have, and they were very fluffy, not dense at all.  The famous tomato sauce though, lacked something. Grant it, I'm not Italian, but have been to Italy a few times, but I even loved the sauce that is in my Soprano's cook book better than this 'famous sauce'.  I had the ravioli that was suggested, a pear/ricotta ravioli in brown butter (could not taste the pear, very bland, needed salt) they weren't sweet or savory (I actually hit it with a squeeze of lemon from my water and it brightened it up).  My husband had the famous lemon chicken, which had a decent char, and but overly lemony.  We've had Italian lemon chicken before, and this wasn't earth shattering or memorable unfortunately.  This was our most expensive and least favorite meal for the entire weekend.  We started here on Thursday, but Friday & Saturday were MUCH better (and less expensive) alternatives.  (Joe's Prime, Once, Momofuku, Hell's Kitchen)

jABmEHuQEREP0bbIFXH7Ew.text: Wowowowow blown away in a BAD way.  Extremely disappointed..not even sure where to start.. The Veal chop was burnt The clams were tiny and dried up. The chicken picatta was also burnt zero flavor. The funny part was that the restaurant was empty...Such a shame they let the quality go down hill. I'm not spoiled. I'm a well traveled foodie who has been eating in hundreds of Italian restaurants around the world..2nd trip there wont be a third. The server was great. Go for dessert and that's it. There are so many Super Quality restaurants on the strip. UPDATE: To be fair the restaurant contacted me and asked me to come by to see if they could fix it. Just hope its not gonna be my last meal..lol

photos.caption: Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States

maotQUxfoQHxvbQsL4Lhgw.text: Went there for early dinner yesterday and had the Cod special... fish was  dry and so overcooked like chewing rubber. I asked the waiter if the fish special was fresh and his exact words in response were "It should be."    6-8 hours later and I'm throwing up.  Never going back to Roa's in Las Vegas.

c0DpT6MFDPXBpWRWzXC9Ag.text: Since the Rao's in NY books one year in advance, I wanted to get to the one in Vegas since they had open reservations & I'm glad I did. First off, I had a lemon vodka/club soda/lemonciello cocktail that was to die for. If you like lemon, order this. Order two. For an appetizer, my husband and I shared the Fritto Misto. The fish wasn't at all chewy and the fried zucchini was a welcome addition. For our entree, we split the Frutta di Mare that was plated tableside and was delicious. Seafood was fresh, pasta was al dente and the sauce was... I mean it's Raos, I had an extra bread basket brought over for the sauce. We also got a side of meatballs and they were huge and tender and melt in your mouth. We didn't mean to get dessert, but we accidentally ordered the profiteroles which were filled with vanilla gelato and yeah, big oops :) Go here! See the Trevi Fountain while you're at it. It'll be like a trip to Italy in half the flight time.

8FqoMlSE82DeGugUbuTtmw.text: 2/4/19- So with all the 4+ star restaurants in Vegas... Rao's is definitely the first 3.5 star restaurant that I have visited. Solely two reasons for this decision. #1, I heard the meatballs were out of this world. #2, there is no way humanly possible that I would ever have the opportunity to visit the original Rao's which is located in Harlem. I can easily say that these were the best meatballs I've ever had. Super moist, loaded with flavor, and very filling. The veal parm was just ok and the spaghetti bolognese was rather dry. I was happy with my 2 cocktails but my BF ended up leaving his practically untouched. Rather disappointing for a $17 cocktail. I enjoyed the music but the sound was a little too low. The servers were very attentive, however, the hostess had a bit of a chip on her shoulder as she tapped her counter signaling for me to leave my drink behind before entering the restaurant. Doubtful I'll be back for another meal... possibly just for meatballs at the bar.

The roasted red pepper with buffalo mozzarella was very good Got the salsa alla marinara which was good. For dessert had the creme brulee .. cold frm inside warm from outside.. it was perfect

T08Mwl2NH3FXp9P6VbPrhQ.text: It's average.  Nothing special.   Pasta was not al dente.  It was over cooked.  I expected more for the price.  However, the service was great and nice atmosphere.

0Hl7OF_uR-FN0BKzdMA--g.text: Worth every penny!!! Felt like I was eating at the new York location. I loved every single thing about this place. The service was extraordinarily!!! Our waiter was amazing. I wish I knew his name!!! The food, omg the food!!! The fried green tomatoes caprese was delicious. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. The penne vodka was soooooo good. So good. Best I've ever had. I can not wait to return. I loved it here.

D8kvwlNiGf6A1M8LObWpVg.text: This is one of the best places in all of Las Vegas. Everything we ordered was absolutely the best around.

Uhg6cPnU76csjYZsUtgIWw.text: We had such a wonderful dinner at Rao's before seeing Celine.  We were greeted extremely quick by our waiter and he remained attentive the entire visit.  We ordered the meatballs as an appetizer and they were AMAZING.  Anyone who claims anything else must have gotten something else because they were so moist you could slice them into thin slices with just your fork.  For the main course, we ordered the penne pasta with vodka sauce and ravioli.  Both items are a MUST - I couldn't decide which one I liked better.  The vodka sauce was so full of flavor and the pasta was cooked perfectly.  The ravioli was perfectly prepared as well with a very nice hint of sweetness from the pear.  For folks who claim it took too long for the food to come out, I disagree.  The dinner was timed perfectly for a relaxing, enjoyable dinner.  If you're in that big of a hurry, there are a ton of fast food joints in Vegas..knock yourselves out!  :)  Great beginning to our evening.  Thanks Rao's!

eKdWxws8t7oc5VoLMCxUGA.text: First time to this restaurant, my mom had been here previously and said it was good which it was! We were seated right away at a nice table with a view of the pool. Our server Russ was really nice, informative and personable. He came over to us promptly and told us the specials and gave us his recommendations which was nice. We ordered drinks and he let us know he was putting in our food once we'd had a minute to enjoy them which was nice. Then our food came out and I was wishing I'd ordered what my mom had! Her ravioli purses were amazing , sweet but also savoury. My meal was way too rich but that's how a carbonara is made. It was the crab carbonara I'd had but to be honest the carb was underwhelming. The portion of crab was minimal and the flavour of it was overpowered by cheese and pepper, it could be fixed so that the crab shines in this dish a bit more. Otherwise, the food was pretty good and the service great- we gambled on this restaurant and I'd say we broken even here.

Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delicious ravioli purses!

owZHEhpjT6cFcH1DA00oYA.text: Top notch hospitality!  Being big fans of the Rao sauce, we were thrilled to have dinner at the Rao's in Las Vegas on 4/5/19.  The restaurant was beautiful inside and out.  The interiors were covered beautifully wall to wall of celebrity photos, and we were promptly seated at a booth in the first main room, near the fireplace with some Christmas decor.  I didn't mind the decor at all because I love Christmas, and thought it added to the old school Italian charm.  +10 points for using the Rao jars for lamps at each table, talk about genius branding!  Our server was attentive, friendly, helpful and courteous, and his services were on point as he acknowledged my husband, kid and I individually.  He suggested a few wines to my husband and even let my husband taste 2 of the house wines, but was never pushy.    The meal came promptly and good portions, the caprese salad was the best we had ever had, everything was so fresh and delicious, especially the delicious balsamic vinegar, which ties and balances everything together so nicely.  Appetizers and entrees were also fantastic, and we enjoyed the table service when our meatball and pasta were plated tableside.  The ambiance and the meal were both very enjoyable and relaxing, and but the grand finale was the most amazing part of our dining experience.  After we were done with dinner, we lingered around the main area because like I mentioned, we are addicted to the Rao sauce at home, so we were drooling over the cookbooks and the merch, and my kid was intrigued by all the old school celebrity photos, so we were really taking our sweet time taking group photos and checking out the merch with my husband.  After one of the matre D kindly offered to take a family photo for us, our kind server, ran towards us, looking extraordinarily excited and happy.  He asked about our meal, making sure we had a good time, in a way that we kinda knew he had something to tell us.  Lo and behold, he handed my husband his phone, which had slipped out onto the booth (probably during payment) at the end of the meal.  We thanked the kind gentleman profusely and truly thought he was the highlight of a perfect meal.  What a class act!  Our dinner met and exceeded my expectations and I was truly in awe of the gentleman's kindness.

O5SVAHzkKUyJDCxWGPQqDw.text: This place is really great. I would recommend going right before closing because it can be a little crowded. It is great for parties of 4 or more. I had the rigatoni which was fantastic, and I tried the meatballs and chicken Parmesan as well. All were great options. The butter for the bread is the only thing I was not a big fan of. The service was quite good and the cocktails looked amazing. Pro tip: if you order an espresso martini you get a free drink shaker!

t9374BkLZdVliGOWPmQ9wg.text: This unique one of a kind family owned  Italian restaurant is amazing. Everything is prepared from scratch, they have had the same recipe for years. They original opened in NYC many years ago and we are so happy they brought their legacy to Las Vegas. First off there sauce is one of kind, I haven't ate sauce like this since my grandmother made it from scratch from ripe Roma tomato's in the backyard. The meatballs are out of this world!!!! If you haven't tried Raos meatballs I suggest you do, I can assure you that you will never eat another meatball from anywhere else again. Everything we order was 1000% authentic Italian food. Just like the way they cook in Italy. Myself, being born to immigrant parents, all they cooked was good Italian food, at Raos, I thought I was back in my parents kitchen.  The baked muscles were out of this world, everything we ate was so good. The atmosphere is very nice, the waitress was a total sweetheart and was so helpful and attentive. I recommend you try this place and I can promise you that you will agree. Raos has been around since 1896, and there's a reason why they are still open today. You could tell all of the dishes are cooked with love. Go there hungry & enjoy a True genuine piece of Italian culture. Thank you Frankie Jr. for everything

5jwkdIfJWAforg6U22AOPw.text: Excellent food and service. Our party had a variety of appetizers, including meatballs. The wine (both red and white) was divine. The chicken Parmesan was nothing to write home about. The lamb lollipops were delicious. Would definitely seek those out again. The chocolate gelato was a great way to end the meal (although others in the party raved about the peanut butter cake). Service was fabulous. Thanks!

UrOcCepTdGfAcvvjAB7COw.text: Excellent atmosphere. Food was fantastic. Service was impeccable. We ate at the bar and our bartender was outstanding. Keith (our bartender) went above and beyond what I had expected. Will definitely return.

X1GUKc9tmYumxwotLESTeg.text: My girlfriend and I are hardcore devotees of Rao's pasta sauces.   Store-bought or not, these lil' jars of flavor can easily elevate any old pasta meal to the next level, thanks a blend of fresh ingredients and an emphasis on natural, genuine flavors. However, despite having spent the better portion of her life in NYC, my girl has never had the chance to visit the actual Rao's outpost in New York's Upper East Side (although you can't really fault her for not being one of the place's dozen or so lucky regulars...!). Thus, in celebrating our six months together earlier this summer, we jumped at the chance to visit the restaurant that bears the very same name as our favorite brand of Italian food products.  The atmosphere at Rao's is homey and down-to-earth. Upon entering, the dark woods and dim lighting immediately transported me from the charged, uptempo atmosphere of the Strip into something akin to Michael Corleone's dining room. The charm at Rao's was all the more amped up by our table, which was located in the restaurant's "Christmas" room (see photos!). Complete with a staggering variety of portraits depicting NYC's who's who, the room does an outstanding job of making you as though you're part of "the club."  The best detail of all, however, was was the loud, borderline obnoxious New Yorker seated one table over - whose accent made him stand out from every other conversation in the room. We couldn't stop giggling at his exclamations to his tablemates ("The food here is absolutely pheNAWmenal!" "Waiter, we're gonna need maw woine!"), and it was thanks to him that our dinner felt pretty much as New York as a meal could get.  The vibes of family and gracious charm were driven home by the fantastic service that we received from a gent whom I believe is named Alex. Despite the flurry of questions thrown (We must've asked him about 6-7 entrees that we were choosing from, each of which he explained in lovingly extensive detail!), Alex never gave us anything less than his undivided attention. I'd give his service six stars, if I could.    We started out with a couple glasses of the house wise, which was refreshing, crisp, and palette cleansing.   The Caprese Salad appetizer was earthy and fresh. The creamy burrata and heirloom tomatoes combined to create a wonderful melding of flavors. The house blend balsamic used at Rao's, however, was a show-stopper; we learned that the vinegar used by Rao's undergoes a specific, twelve-year aging process (so as to maximize its depth of flavor). The results of this process were easy to identify, and I had to pry myself away from a second bread basket to make room for the rest of my meal.   In the hopes of getting a full idea of what the menu at Rao's had to offer, we ordered three entrees - my girlfriend got the Spaghetti Bolognese, I ordered Beef Lasagna, and we tacked on a serving of Uncle Vincent's Lemon Chicken, too. (Needless to say. we were in full indulgence mode.)  Our food was brought out quickly, and in mammoth portions; my Lasagna alone seemed like it could've been used as a boat anchor. These big serving sizes were much appreciated, however - as the flavors of Rao's entrees were just as massive and satisfying. The bolognese blends used in our two pasta dishes were fantastic, striking a welcome balance between meatiness and crisp tomato flavor. My lasagna had to have been seven or eight layers deep - with ricotta, parmesan, and mozzarella lending a creaminess that counterbalanced the umami meat flavors of the bolognese.  The Lemon Chicken was juicy and had a great char. The strong lemon flavor paired off well in between bites of tomato sauce-laden pasta, but I'm not sure if I would have enjoyed a full serving of this dish on its own. The tanginess might have gotten a little played out without accompaniment from another entree.  The icing on the cake for our Rao's experience was that of our unexpected dessert course (no pun intended!). While being seated, I briefly mentioned that my girlfriend and I were celebrating an anniversary. Although the GF and I were given a dessert menu to scope out towards the conclusion of our meal - a very clever deception tactic on the part of the Rao's staff - we were entirely blindsided when Alex presented us with a heaping (and free!!!) portion of Caramel Apple Cheesecake, complete with a message from the chef. As he explained, "a little birdy" had happened to mention that we were commemorating a special occasion, and we were absolutely swept off our feet by this unexpected gesture of hospitality. With plenty of leftovers, my girlfriend and I waddled out of Rao's with the biggest grins on our faces!  According to its menu, Rao's has been serving up homestyle Italian food for over a century. All this practice definitely amounted to something - I haven't had an Italian meal this memorable in a long time, if ever. Paying another visit to Rao's is near the top of my things to do the next time I'm in Sin City.

Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. We were seated in a lovely area called &#34;The Christmas Room&#34;

wJBDfDOtWbalyszMB4arww.text: Had an enjoyable meal to celebrate my daughter's college graduation. One meal was late in coming out to the table, but the dishes were delicious.

fce097XxAQ5CFjLFQ074XQ.text: I came to Rao's with my Husband and two guys from his work because they were in town on business. We had seen Rao's on TV years ago on the Food Network, so of course we made a point to stop by when we were in Las Vegas.  I was able to make reservations for 7:00pm on a Friday earlier that same day and they had plenty of reservation spots available. There was also no wait when we arrived, so it's easy to get into. Exactly the opposite of the New York location!  They started with the Fritto Misto which was supposed to be a mix of three different kinds of seafood, but ended up to be mostly calamari. I had a cup of their made in house Tomato Soup with was great and came with fried cheese which was a nice tasty touch.  They had two different vegetarian pastas for entrees, so I had the Ricotta and Pear Purses in the Brown Butter Sauce. They were great! I loved the pears with the cheese, and the pasta was cooked perfectly. They make them in house, and you can tell.  My Husband had the Veal Piccata which was HUGE and my Husband really liked it. He had never had it before, but thought it had great flavor. It was such a large portion that he couldn't even finish it which is hard to do!  Service was great and attentive, and we decided that we would come back again. It wasn't my favorite Italian restaurant, but I'm glad we went.

iVRFKzL2WoqQ1PkI-3M_wQ.text: This was our first night at Caesar Palace and a bartender recommended Rao's for Italian. The decor or the restaurant was beautiful but that is where it ended. The wait staff acted is they were doing us a favor by letting us eat there.  Our head waiter was more interested BS'ing to his friend at the next table than waiting on us. Finally after ordering, the food came out quickly.  But I have had better Italian out of a chef boy r d can.  The bill came to $130 for a glass of wine, lasagne and a spaghetti, no appetizer or salad. Don't waste your time or money especially when there are fabulous restaurants like Bobby Flay's at Caesar's Palace.

ufdmp-rI3-cw3v9HXW8wdQ.text: This place has a nice Italian feel to it when you walk in. We got seated and it was really dark inside. I get it; they want to set the mood for an Italian, old style feel but it was to the point where we had to put a light from our cell phones towards the menus to read them. Our waiter was very nice. The problem I had was that this place is very pricey and we had to wait a good 45 min to close to an hour for our food. I would understand if the place was crowded but it wasn't. There were several empty tables. My meal was delicious as well as everyone else in our party but do I think it's over priced for the average service we received? Yes. If I'm paying $30-50 per plate, I expect to receive superior and fast service. This was not the waiters' fault. He was nice. I'd say save your money and find another place to eat.

9VcbUwCA6oek67lmZZDZTQ.text: Overrated. Bolognese sauce was too salty. Very expensive for very ordinary food. Another issue - wow the Caesars Palace crowd is rough. Drunks and individuals coming in from the pool with no cover up and trust me, you did not want to see this. Very poor atmosphere for such an expensive meal.

D95BznwR0DhCjCX6eXt1Fg.text: Was excited to try Rao's as we have heard great things from the NYC location. However, we weren't that impressed dining at the Vegas location. I mean the food was good but the portions are small for the prices you pay. We ordered the meatballs, beet salad, caprese salad to start and for dinner house salad, eggplant parmesan, two orders of beef lasagna. Sounds like a lot but it really wasn't. The cheque was a lot for what we ordered. Service was nice, but probably wouldn't go back. Tables and chairs were not comfortable lol but I think they do that to resemble the old school NY restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Birthday Dessert
Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Eggplant Parmesan
Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Appetizers, mozzarella salad, beet salad &amp; meatballs

Y1Ddk_ol7VqQo1vSQu_10g.text: We went there after our wedding. The staff was very kind and helpful, the ambiance was very romantic like we wanted. The food was excellent; we shared Rao's meatballs and Chicken Parmesan and it was just excellent. The dessert was also excellent and we got a nice "Congratulations" on our plate wish was very kind of them. We are glad to not have listened other reviews because this restaurant is definitely under-rated. Excellent restaurant.

W9tQ7DpOgRnjnzpIDgV-Fw.text: Showing up here in March for dinner was a bit of a surreal experience.  Some of us arrived early and went to the bar for a drink before dinner.  Christmas decorations were still up - poinsettias and wreaths - what's up with that?  When the rest of the group show up, we go to the hostess stand to be seated.  I asked if we were going to be seated in one of the back rooms which, according to Yelpers, was very nice.  "Of course, sir, we have you seated in one of our very nice replica rooms in the back," was the reply.  We were led back to our table in the back.  While every other table in the room was carefully and orderly situated, our table appeared to be slapped down in an awkwardly right in front of the kitchen door.  Our table and our group stuck out like a sore thumb.  But our view of the dishwashing area of the kitchen was great!  The food is "traditional" Americanized Italian place.  Red sauce, pasta, cheese, etc.  The meatballs were justifiably worth getting - moist and savory - not the best but pretty dang good.  Pastas were ok, meats were ok.  Portions were large.  Service was uninspired.      Competent? Yes.  Memorable? No.

2yylRlVCDI0g8OyRruzE6g.text: Sat at the bar pre-show, after our ambitious attempt to go to Bacchanal on a time constraint failed miserably.  Not a bad Plan-b! Our bartender/server was friendly and delightful (shamefully I've forgotten his name). The bread and butter were sinful, as expected at a solid Italian establishment. I had a nice glass of rose- another worthy name forgotten, oops.  The food was tasty and satisfying- three of us (dainty ladies) split a fresh and tangy Caesar salad, linguini with clams (I scraped the bowl for more tender, tasty clams and wasn't disappointed), and 2 house meatballs. We were too full for dessert by the end, and almost late for our show!  The ambience is dark and rich, not unlike what you'd expect to see in some mafia movie. I've never been to the original location in NYC so I can't compare.  A nice surprise!

KuYZA2m-moODNN7o_77t3Q.text: This place is delicious!  Not sure what the bad reviews were about except that it was expensive?  Yea....  it's expensive.  If you want a cheaper meal, go to Boca De Beppo down the street at Excalibur.  If you want quality food, come here.  Robert the bartender is awesome as well

uhVzciP7xUOJA89nKS64_Q.text: Wow! What an amazing meal.  My husband and I started with the meatballs as our appetizer. They were flavorful and the texture was amazing. I can't say enough how much we both loved the sauce they were served in, and fresh grated cheese...YES! For dinner he has the lasagna. He's always loved my lasagna, and He now has a new favorite.  I had the Pomodoro. Amazing. The sauce was so rich and seasoned perfectly.  We finished the evening with the tiramisu. Wonderful, sweet, but not too sweet. Perfect consistence, very moist lady fingers. Everything was amazing. Can't wait to eat here again.

photos.caption: Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tiramisu deliciousness!
Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The best meatballs ever!

_6pr0Xq3A3I1Bf22pOeNAg.text: Don't let the size of the front entrance fool you.  This restaurant is huge!    Our party of 8 certainly enjoyed our dinner.  Service was excellent.  Christmas decorations created a certain ambience of old family Italian restaurant.  Meatballs, Ceasar salad, and the spaghetti were excellent, with flavorful sauce but yet not too tomatoe-y basil flavor.  After reading all of the other reviews, I ordered the lemon chicken.  The lemon chicken was just okay.  I wouldn't order it again.   It wasn't the best Italian meal I've had in Vegas (that's reserved for Martorano's at Paris), yet I would go back if I were at Ceasar's.

VnelGYnhkUxC6DwyA137MQ.text: I am an Italian American from New Jersey.  This is delicious food carefully prepared in the style I was raised with.  The calamari is perfectly fried and not chewy.  The ravioli purses were sweet, salty,buttery and heavenly.  Meatballs are up there with my Aunties and the lemon chicken was perfect.  Tiramisu was housemade, fresh, fluffy and creamy.  This was a hosted dinner so I did not pay and the red wine was flowing.  Good time was had by all and a must visit with a group.

CIzQ_0D0iFb5PpVuKkcOIQ.text: Excellent...great atmosphere, great service, great food. We had the meatball appetizer to start and the meat was so tender and moist, cooked to perfection. For the main course we had penne vodka and the fish of the day, both were perfect!

n-dqRFFkZW-PmjHM3CSOKg.text: The service it's great, people who really like to work!  Great time, the pasta can be improved at least a spaghetti a marinara and meatballs! The sauce kind of dry. But the salad and the mozzarella perfect!

7Drq7m7yLVDRAzMQv_0LlA.text: You will just love this place the place is so nice hidden but amazing. The food is incredible you will love there capresse salad that's honestly my favorite thing to get. The staff is incredible and so are the managers. I've been here a couple of times and I'll keep on returning.

xucSaIxo8smjVAP6muTqYQ.text: Omg this place its so good very authentic Italian food , I think just about everything is delicious in this place I very really go back to eat at the same places but I have been here like 6 times never disappointed love there staff they make you feel very welcome.

wYEsY8_N4taXPCUtsrEprw.text: Rao's Las Vegas is a home-style Italian American eatery that feels like you've stepped back in time, the walls are covered with framed items and year round Christmas decorations.  The menu is designed for you go with a group and eat family-style.  For our First Course we had the Fritto Misto which was a pile of battered and deep fried shredded zucchini, calamari, and a few pieces of shrimp and cod served with marinara and tarter sauces.  It was a large appetizer which could easily be shared between 5-6 people, but it was nothing special.  A bit greasy, a bit bland, I didn't want any more after a few bites.  For our Second Course we had the Penne Vodka.  The penne was pretty al dente, probably the least cooked you could eat pasta without complaining it was still raw.  The pink prosciutto, tomato-cream sauce was tasty.  Portion wise this could have easily been split by 3-4 as a first entree.  For our Third Course we had the Ossobuco, a huge veal shank with saffron risotto.  The veal wasn't as tender as I would have hoped, it didn't fall off the bone and wasn't deep and rich in flavor.  I couldn't taste the saffron in the risotto and it was wet in texture from the veal jus poured over it.  As a second entree, this could have been shared by 3-4.  For a Side, we ordered the Rao's Meatball which was tender and moist, but a bit bland, and big enough for 4 to share.  We skipped the Fourth Course, dessert, because we were full and with three lack-luster courses under our belts decided we were done.  For 2 people, without drinks, our meal was $158.00, and the leftovers we took home could have easily fed 2 more.  For the price, there are definitely better eats in Vegas.  If you do want to try Rao's, come with a group to help you eat the volume of food and spread out the cost.
