GBaB_36FWyjGcOQumn4PEQ.text: Meatballs, chicken parm, oh my! The meatballs (appetizer) were huge, juicy, and flavorful. The bartender was friendly and attentive. He quickly recognized that my colleague's scampi was wrong. Aside from that snafoo, it was a great experience!

NIwxKTqIXNdEN7X6T59_Lw.text: This place is the best restaurant in Ceasars, it's not cheap but it's worth every penny. I would choose this place over the homestead any night. Got the Osobucco and wow is all I could say.

nLdYps3CyJ-tQtJgpwhBCA.text: Great food and service. The pasta was amazing and the desserts were to die for.  The staff was friendly and on top of their game. Will be visiting again when I get the chance.

A4LBQAfU60G38fOdABbGRw.text: After hearing all about their meatballs, I went to Rao's and ordered their Lemon Chicken.  I'm so against-the-grain, you don't even know.  The chicken was very good.  It was tender and surprisingly flavorful for something that sounds so "plain" and "boring" next to other Rao's menu items.  The service was excellent, especially with selecting and describing their wine list.  My boss is a huge wine snob so our group generally goes through a half dozen bottles at dinner -- I must recommend Rao's Sicilian reds which are tremendous.  Ask your server for a Sicilian that will cater to your tastes.  All of them are excellent.  The restaurant, itself, is somewhat interesting.  The decorations are on par with other traditional Italian sit-down places.  A 360 bar serves as the restaurant's center hub, and various large rooms shoot off of this area.  There is a fake outdoor area by the entrance, which is next to a fountain inside Caesars Palace.  This area can get pretty loud so I would recommend against sitting here.  Alternatively, there is a real outdoor area which faces Caesars' pool.  The pool closes relatively early so there won't be much noise from there but you will get some residual sound from the Strip's traffic.  Overall, this is a nice place for a nice dinner.  The service is excellent and the food is pretty good.  Oh, and I came back again for the meatballs and even though they were hyped, I enjoyed them immensely.  Order them on the side if you can.

LnKsSTpICjKKXJoqZJa9mg.text: This place is ok - for half the price it would be a good place to eat.  Mozzarella in carozza - ok - needed more cheese. octopus- ok - needed more lemon and olive oil. orecchiette with rape and sausage - ok but I make this much better. Canoli - very good.  For the price, this is no bargain.

n6JHIKQnhdXS6RyuuC_sIg.text: WOW!  What a disappointment!  I am from the NYC area and love good Italian food.  I agree I am spoiled from the old days in Brooklyn when one could get a truly great Italian meal at any of dozens of places.  Most you would not go into, unless you knew better.  I am please to say no one was ever shot while I was dining  those many times.  Both service and food reached out to re-define mediocrity.  Our waiter regularly disappeared and treated us like we were an old buddy he never really liked.  The only food that had some greatness was the Antipasto which had great roasted peppers, cheeses and good meats, not much of the meats, but good.  The artichokes they served on the antipasto were horrible.  I think they were spoiled.  The stuffed clams were more like a game of Where's Waldo, clams being waldo.  Our entrees, two pasta dishes, ah, so so.  $150 later (two mixed drinks at $11.50 each) I was left feeling I had just lost at one of the tables...  Only this one I will never come back to.  Let me not forget to mention the mindless hostesses.  Never again.  OH, BTW, I now live in Veagas,and will warn all my friends to stay away!

ghwkjY7wqAt_HrgXMFMrkQ.text: The Sauce on the gnocchi was delicious (pork, veal, beef - how can you go wrong), but the gnocchi wasn't as firm as I liked. The SO had Scarpollini (sp) and she loved it (that is her favorite Italian Dish). Tasted the chicken in it and it was pretty dang tasty.  This is classic italian food.

lwYMrF7MwG1uicYQuRnMDA.text: Although I enjoyed Rao's, it's probably a bit overpriced for the quantity and quality of food received. The restaurant is located next to the pool at Caesar's Palace. Finding the place was a bitch. There are three dining rooms, two of which replicate the original vibe of the Rao's in NYC. I'd suggest requesting one of the 'original' Rao's rooms (tons of photos, Christmas lights, etc.) instead of the third dining area near the pool (which isn't very interesting). You enter the restaurant and walk through a great bar area to get to your table. The wait staff is pretty good - but I'd definitely ask for one of the New Yorkers imported to offer a higher level of service.   I had grilled zucchini with crabmeat and shrimp which was DELISH. I split an order of lemon chicken (very moist and full of lemony flavor - and a great dish. $24) and penne alla vodka (very good - $20). I'd come to Rao's thinking that the servings would be 'family-sized' but they were really only sufficient for two adults with not much of an appetite. The house Chianti was very good, too. Finished with tiramisu and coffee. Would definitely go back to Rao's even though I'd probably nosh on a few things at the cool bar area.

h2vozwOj1Qr0g2ViL2kB3g.text: Oh Rao's I am so happy we met. This is good, solid Italian food. Yes the menu is limited but what they do, they do well. Service was good, attentive without being disruptive.  Special faves, the ravioli purses and the Veal Parm.

u8naT4Sc7Yb19Lp8GpE70g.text: Don't believe the hype. This place doesn't live up to its New York-built reputation. It looks good, but its food is something else.  We started with an appetizer of octopus and broccoli rabe. The meat was burnt on the outside, tough on the inside -- way overcooked. I wish I'd sent it back. The broccoli rabe was good, though. We chose two pasta dishes as our main courses. We kind of enjoyed the gnocchi in a ground meat and tomato sauce; the gnocchi themselves weren't too heavy (although I've certainly had lighter), and the sauce was tasty enough, albeit slightly peppery. Unfortunately, the orrechiette with sausage and broccoli rabe was swimming in olive oil. After dinner, we consulted the Rao's cookbook that was for sale in the store adjoining the restaurant and guessed that there was probably twice the amount of oil in our dish than was called for in its recipe. Again, the broccoli rabe was tasty, but the sausage was overcooked. We paid far too much for this food, too.  Some good stuff: Friendly, mostly attentive service. Nice decor. Fun, kitschy music from different decades. Stay away if you want truly top-notch Italian food in Vegas, though.

qLoxZjZdtvA-_pCjyuJNWw.text: Very good italian restaurant within Caesar's Palace. We've had dinner here twice and both times were great. Their meatballs are fantastic. The service staff are knowledgable, helpful, and friendly. You can't ask for better.

GVhJC7Lhr68ufff-NV10Eg.text: Was disgusted with the service here. I came to eat with a group of 13 and at the end of the meal they refused to split up our check. It left us having to do a lot of math to try and split up our own check and after an hour of trying to do that our check still ended up being short and someone had to pay ten extra dollars for their meal. On top of that they only allowed 6 debits cards?! A girl didn't know what to do at our table because all she brought was a debit card to pay with. For a restaurant in the middle of Caesars palace Las Vegas, they need to learn how to split up the checks. By the end of the meal everyone was frustrated with having spent an extra hour there trying to split up the check that it ruined everyone's evening. Everyone ended up fighting with each other over the check issue and it just wasn't worth it. When we talked to the manager about it she was extremely rude and didn't even help us. I mean geez the least she could do was give us a free bottle of wine or something. Absolutely ridiculous and everyone should avoid this restaurant by all means. I'll never be returning.

diwj7S5cJl6GFcOusPSkTA.text: Originally from NYC & now living in Vegas, family and friends from both Hawaii and NY visited me last week 7/13/12. We were so excited to go to Rao's for dinner and was quickly disappointed with the meal.  The antipasta & meatball appetizer was good. The five of us had the worst Italian meal ever. I had the famous Lemon Chicken - reminded me more like they caught a pigeon. Extremely dry with not even a sprig of parsely to dress up the plate - no sides came with it. The lemon sauce was extremely sour - they should just get rid of this dish. Our bill was close to $500 which included two bottles of wine - what a waste of money! Carmine's is opening up at Caesars soon - Rao's close your doors - here comes real Italian food!  Stay away!

XkvF2sCYE0x_HPIoKHqd6g.text: This has become my "go to" place in Vegas.  I assume the draw is partly subliminal - when I lived in NYC I called the one there a couple times for a reservation, was told "call back next year", and we go through 5 - 6 large jars of their pasta sauce every month.  the food is good, but not great, Italian.  The buffalo mozzarella in the appetizer is excellent.  The service is good but the waiters have an annoying habit of sitting down at your table - so now if I go with an odd number of people, I always move the extra chair to another table.  The deserts are good, but the one time I ordered grappa it was the gasoline-harsh kind.  Also one time the cast of the View sat at the table next to us - which would have been very exciting had Star Jones still been around

VDy0COOdNhTzAFncNYcvTQ.text: I have waited to give this place a second visit before writing a review, because the first visit (Jan 09) was so stellar that it was almost too good to be True. The second visit was a little more than a solid 3 star (especially when considering the price), so I think I'll be generous with the average and maybe give this place one more shot before moving on to other high-end dining in Las Vegas.   In fact, I was just in NYC last month, but I didn't even bother to call Rao's as I knew it was futile.....I was geared up for my trip to Las Vegas in the coming weeks.  As mentioned, the first visit was phenomenal. The service was almost too attentive, our waiter told us about the history of Rao's (I grew up in CT, kinda of knew, but not really), gave us an excellent rundown of the menu and allowed us to be unpretentious with our wine choices. Two of us were sat in a booth in a busy, but sociable room off to the left side.   We went for the full-bellied Italian order of the Mozzarella in Carrozza, arugula salad, veal parm (on the bone!), with the tomato and ham vodka cream pasta. Oh, and don't forget the meatballs and gravy.....   Although we were in a food coma (need to upload picture to prove it), we enjoyed the meal and wine thoroughly (and dreamt about the meatballs for months). We couldn't wait to come again.   Our next visit was in July 09. We had a Caesar's concierge make our reservations and dined at a more reasonable hour before 9pm. Although the house was packed, we had a very competent, but indifferent waiter who may have spent too many years in the business to add anything special to the experience. With no other guidance other than "whataya want?", we fumbled our way without an app (no recommendation, no order), warm white wine (I had face my trashy side and put ice cubes in the wine) an uninspiring salad, and somehow, the "parm and balls" just didn't hit the same high notes. After moving to red, we didn't even finish the bottle.   Maybe it was the summer season, the heat taking it's toll, the down economy on Vegas, or something hidden, but the place didn't have the twinkle of that first visit.   Oh Rao's, if you want America to buy those sauces and pastas now found from Kroger to Shop Rite, you better give people a memorable experience in your carnival sized restaurant.   Alas, I'll give it one more try, if I'm not broke off playing craps by the time dinner rolls around that evening....

mDq5xwsMFwZGdx1tfGj85g.text: This was the second time at Rao's in Caesars.  We have the Rao's cookbook so we know what is on the menu.  My wife had the orchiette/brocoli rabe and I had the Linguine clams.  Both our meals were disappointing.  Seasoning and sauces were way over the top.  Salt and garlic were the main culprits.  An hour later I was dying for some water.

GBXFT89JXuqeSGELBuoCfA.text: I'm in love with the food, but could totally lose the sloooow service

8IhfqMEWjw53Km1OmAUNfQ.text: We ate here with some of my boyfriend's hometown friends. The food  was pretty decent, all fresh-tasting Italian. The vodka pasta the other couple mostly split was well-seasoned and wonderful, but not really worth the price tag. The steak with warmed tomatoes, one of the veal dishes, and a broccolini/sweet sausage pasta dish rounded out the meal...all very good dishes, but nothing outstanding or really that memorable. I love Italian food and pasta, but Rao's was a tad overpriced. The portions were large, but the 4 of us opted to share everything "family-style," to taste more dishes...which I also HIGHLY reccomend. I think if we had all picked one dish, we either would have been bored, disappointed, or spent too much and had too much left over to order courses.   The waiter was extremely knowledgable about the food, restaurant, chef, wine, etc....but he was sort of obnoxious and in our faces and too much....It was also a little strange to me how much information he went on about...at a nicer place like that, to just assume all of the diners were idiots with an utter lack of food knowledge was a little strange. The waiter often explained dishes and items to us, like describing the different levels of doneness for steak, explaining that broccolini is bitter, etc...I think maybe a different table of people might have loved his comments better, but oh well. All in all this place was just ok, not somewhere I'd bring friends in town to, but I would absolutely eat here meeting people.

Sz7gVlR_qkJ8hpoPAasd1A.text: Wait staff was prompt and professional, but I did not experience the overly friendly atmosphere that other yelpers have talked about.   Outside of the prompt service, I can't say much else positive about Rao. My Gnocchi was fine (but nothing special) and the Veal, Beef, and Pork combo sauce that it was served with was best described by one of my co-patrons, "It tastes like Ragu!" The meatballs were good, but again, not great. The highlight of our meal was probably the ample amount of bread that was served along with a very tasty bottle of olive oil.  In my unprofessional opinion, Rao is a place that gained notoriety not for its food, but for the smallness of its original location in New York. Any restaurant that charges many thousands of dollars to "buy" its tables for the year is bound to create buzz and I believe Rao Las Vegas has ridden that buzz all the way from Harlem. If you're in Vegas for a month, Rao might be a viable dinner stop for your trip, but for the majority of Vegas tourists, your money is MUCH better spent elsewhere.

PsWAn7prENt7JBodTowc3w.text: Good italian food but a little expensive. Great waiters though.

5SJtCL4CmGgEJdZDa7ApHw.text: I first had RAOs at an Epicurean event and had to try it again.  I had the ravioli purses, which is what I tried at the Epicurean, and it was just as good as I remembered (I am still thinking at it!).  The meatballs were huge and delicious as well.  I would come back again and again for those two things!

3E2ihA3l6vbH1xaDMlxPhw.text: Yum, yum, yum.  I've been wanting to try this place for a long time but finally made it there this past weekend.  We had the 'Fritto Misto di Mare' appetizer (Deep Fried Calamari, Shrimp, Cod Fish and Julienne Zucchini with Remoulade and Marinara Sauce); the marinara sauce was delicious (the hubby liked the Remoulade sauce, which is like tartar sauce) and the batter was light so it didn't feel greesy.    I had the Fusilli con Cavolo e Salsicce (Hot and Sweet Italian Sausage and Cabbage in San Marzano Tomato Sauce) and I enjoyed my dish very much.  I wasn't able to finish it and I was sad to not being able to take it to go (not a fan of cold pasta).  The cabbage in the tomato sauce was very good.  The hubby had Linguine al Vongole Marechiara (New Zealand Cockle Clams Sauteed with Garlic, White Wine and Parsley Topped with a Touch of Tomatoes and Spice) and he loved it.  Can't wait to go back.

4Jt5jwoVodR8_gvZdrmFPw.text: This was definitely a memorable meal.  I loved the veal parm so much that the wait staff thinks I might have set a record for fastest time to finish it.  I paired it with a barbera wine.  That was perfect.  Dessert was a chocolate and peanut butter creation that I still had room for.  It's not a cheap place to go, but worth eating at once during a trip to Vegas.

ksPzyx9icW_JJ1FEtnsR6Q.text: The guy and I took a trip to Vegas recently, and we were very excited to eat at Rao's, especially since we had just seen this place on "Throwdown- with Bobby Flay." We were lucky to get in at all; the adorable host found us a seat int he bar area, which made for a much more relaxed dining experience. Actually, I think I would have preferred sitting there to the main area (or the "outside"); our meal was served more quickly and was way more low-key. I had the salmon pasta which was deliciously fishy and flavorful. My husband pasta with clams which was also excellent. Sure it was pricey, but it is Vegas, and it was so worth it.

af_kQjP9ichymtaO0s1PTA.text: Had a fabulous dinner at Rao's! Setting is great - lively, good energy, but enough privacy to carry on a conversation. We started wtih the baked clams and a caesar salad. Both were delicious. Then had the rigatoni filetto and the veal picatta. The pasta was incredible. Tasted the oinion and pancetta but it was't overpowering - it was perfectly balanced. The pasta was cooked just right. The veal was tender and the sauce was great. In addition to great food, the service was amazing. I wasn't feeling great that night and didn't dig into the pasta with my usual gusto. I didn't realize it, but the owner (manager?) must have been watching and came to our table to ask if everything was okay, and offered to prepare something different for us. I had to let him know, it wasn't the food - it was me. Great service, great food - can't wait to go back during our next trip to Vegas.

90mM5qumN2kbOGa1je4v8w.text: This was quite disappointing. With all the choices in vegas me and a friend settled on this after seeing Raos on throwdown with Bobby Flay. Needless to say I was so excited to try this but this food at best was average. The appetizer of fried calamari was delicious but than again fried calamari is not the most difficult dish to make. I had the gnocchi which was not memorable and pretty bland and my friend had a chicken sausage dish. The chicken was tasty but the overall dish was just not special.It was an odd combo of chicken,veggies and sausage that did not seem to meld together well. For $90 without drinks I would expect a little bit more especially with so much competition on every corner. Maybe we should have tried Mesa Grill which is in the same hotel because this did not hit the mark.

aznf5nCiqJhS5oq1ZQ3jGQ.text: This place was a pleasant surprise.  The food was excellent and the service made it even better. I will be back for sure!

1XCOF-oBk-99_4fvbiSXmA.text: Compared to 2 years ago, the service here is way better. They were trying to create hype by making you wait 30 mins for your table. Now they seem to get the picture. Food is above average. If you order the meatballs, make sure you tell them it should come up with the main course and not as an appetizers. It gets cold fast so eat it quickly.  The profiteroles are good but inconsistent b/w visits. Portions sizes have also come down since they first opened.

eo11EQNx2qZ1Lu66tnboRg.text: This place was great, and the meat balls, probably the best on the planet. This was a place I was looking forward to going, but like other places in town, the food quickly followed the order, there was little time for enjoyment of the ambiance before we ordered, got the food, ate and was gone, fast food dining timeline with a much higher price tag. I do highly recommend this place, just purposefully take your time and enjoy the good job they did decorating the place and figuring out who is in the pictures on the walls.

M1Ixye_UhkGbpiTkoHHWrw.text: I read some less than wonderful reviews but really wanted to check this place out because I am a NY Italian food fan from way back. This place does a very good job and they do charge an arm and a leg for it.  The place is a little hard to find in sprawling Caesar's Palace, but once we got there, the staff and the server were perfect.  The server was helpful and attentive without it being overwhelming.  In other words, he let us enjoy our meal. The food was very nice.  I had the Lemon Chicken which was excellent.  My old lady had a dish with spicy sausage that was REALLY spicy.  We split an order of basically spaghetti and meatballs, and the meatballs are outstanding.  We were too stuffed to have desert and the desert options did not thrill me anyway (canolli, tiramisu, etc. - not anything you could not get at a pizza place - not speaking to the quality, but it was just a little predictable). The bill was a little high and I do not think I would go back again without hitting a big jackpot.  However, I definitely do not regret going either.

K-pmGCXXgfj8bvIqQ1ZLVQ.text: For all the hype that came along with this place I was extremely disappointed. The food came out super slow and when it did it was average at best. Nowhere near worth the hype and definitely not worth the price. They did do the right thing by comping our appetizers cause it took almost an hour for them to come out but there is little else to say positive about this particular experience.

ioNeujpTJSbi3L7GVAZC0A.text: I was so disappointed. I'm still disappointed. This place was supposed to be the best Italian food ever and quite frankly it wasn't. I like the layout of the place, its beautiful and the people that work here are awesome, but my expectations were so high for the food to be so low. I would come back though. I dont know when since there are so many other restaurants to try in LV, but if this was one of the only places open on a certain day then yes count me in. I don't even remember what I ordered. THAT is a bad sign. Their bread was tasty though.

IC8_MxE-6qMyJ5EzaqepLg.text: yo! what an awesome place for dinner, especially convenient when you're staying at ceasar's palace tower. our initial attempt at getting a table failed terribly which meant we had to settle for an 8pm reservation - two hours of more gambling and drinking before dinner (empty stomach) sure doesn't help. anyways, I had the fusilli con cavolo e salsicce (basically fusillii pasts with pork sausages in a red sauce). i loved it, great filling food to combat all that alcohol already in your stomach. We ordered a few meatballs and the waitress was quite literal when she said baseball sized!  eat up here especially when the office is pickup the tab, otherwise spend you money on the crap tables...

pOGcKfEnKDBQOH96GODkWQ.text: Sunday supper before going to watch a show we all gathered for our last meal in Vegas. I'm not sure if i just wasn't in the mood for italian or if the decor just got me down. The wife and i ordered the filet mignon and the fried mozzarella. The steak was cooked perfectly medium, with a tasty risotto (although a little salty).  The decor seems like a cheesy pizza joint with all the pictures on the wall, and the place seems centered around their bar.

BTJAaLdkAhERNR8iz-SVPw.text: Was staying at Caesars for a conference and ate here. The best Italian meal I have ever had. Must try the meatballs. Plus our server was fantastic and made us feel like family. Place gets busy but worth the wait!

9WmPFTIvgEbQ9wKMNwK_xw.text: We found this place while walking around Caesar's Palace last weekend and we found our way to a gem! We sat outside in the closest table near a public ramp so unfortunately, with 6 girls, we had a lot of unwanted male visits to our table while the guys were on their way into the place. Aside from this, our dining experience was great. The service was wonderful and the food was great. It was pretty big portions and the flavors were awesome. I had the meatballs which had me at bite one. They are the most moist, flavorful, meatballs you will ever eat. Others had some pasta dishes and also the salmon but the highlight of my meal were the meatballs. There were 2 in a dish and each were the size of baseballs. Remember to share when you go here or you won't be able to go clubbing afterwards on your full tummy!

k8toz2Z3aw6V0pmXGn9uDQ.text: Just another average Italian restaurant for me. The meatballs were alright not spectacular. Everything else was just alright for me. The place is very nice and the decor is quite elegant. Service was better than average.

tUmgWdLq0YhjhWzXs-pgcg.text: Rao's was delicious! Service was also great. I am a fan of bread, and theres was pretty good, they also had these delicous parmesan crackers :). We shared the seafood salad (it's large enough to split), a meatball (appetizer), and for my dinner I had  Pan-Seared Pork Chop, Topped with Sauteed Hot and Sweet Cherry Peppers. The pork chop was hands down one of the best I've ever had. VERY flavorful, it was like the food was dancing in your mouth. DEFINITELY recommend it!

umtZtjFOxrJfsXqh9gQ4Hw.text: One of the best meatballs I've ever had. I had the veal parmigiana for my main course and it was great. Overall a great experience and location.

36il5IXxFln8-YW98gchow.text: decent food but very expensive. the motif isn't too appealing either. service was efficient and friendly. definitely not as good as the one in NYC.

YmlIGi4Z9-9v5tFia5ohVg.text: SOOOOOO good The food is authentic and delicious. Vegas is filled with great places to eat but this is a must. The meatball is amazing.

Mu2dYE9xMr7gwHSJ_-0Ivw.text: I am sorry to say just how bad this was. We had a lactose intolerant person with us and they got so badly treated we will never again be back. The waiter said, "it's an Italian restaurant, whaddya expect!".  Very poor!

745DO9ToR7mODW13t9m3tg.text: A comfy bar stool and small lunch menu were just what I needed when I walk into Rao's for a super late lunch.   The trick to eating well in Vegas is finding a place that has decent food without the insane tourist prices - I think Rao's is one of these places.   I sat down, famished from a hard day's work (no, seriously) I spent a week in Vegas working, not gambling or partying like most. For this reason I could appreciate the dark wood colors and dim lighting in this restaurant.   Essentially the reason why I'm giving Rao's such high stars is because their server was efficient, their food was good and I didn't blow my whole per-diem in one sitting. Actually, I lie, there's more to Rao's than that, there is an amazing Caesar Salad, yes salad.   Anyone who knows me knows that while I enjoy the ingredients that go into making salads, the dish just loses its appeal once they've all been tossed together. That was not the case here, the huge shaves of parmesan cheese, delicious crispy croutons and fresh tasty dressing made this salad a memorable one.   Thank you Rao's, your comfy chair and no nonsense lunch menu saved my tummy!

Rk6sQ6pb7qEdclvhV5jYwQ.text: This is probably the poorest managed property on the caesars list of restaurants. We have tried to eat there twice on their casino floor patio but both times were told the patio was closed because of not enough waiters. This is for the general manager: Staff your patio first and you will see the influx coming in. Your patio full of customers eating is your best asset. You may as well put a closed for business sign out front and it will be more appropriate. Unbelievable.

33dKGJDkyuG6QQpos3LkFA.text: Excellent service! Excellent entries! True, it's a little pricey, but it's a sophisticated restaurant at Caesar's Palace - go figure. I had the beef lasagna, it just melts in your mouth it was so good!! The waitress we had was very attentive, quick, and very nice. That's how it should be at every restaurant! I would go to Rao's for special occasions. If you go on a holiday, just remember to make reservations well in advance.

Z0dZCL8KYYPaz5FMAJe4iw.text: I have wanted to go to the Rao's in NYC for about twenty years.... So I tried the Vegas location and all I have to say is, Wow what mediocre food you have !! I started off with a salad that was fresh and delicious 5 stars.... Then my spaghetti bolognese came and it was sooooo bland way to much basil.... Like wtf are you thinking amount of basil. I  had to cover the entire thing is cheese just to get it down. PS they gave me boxed spaghetti for over $30 a plate I should be getting home made pasta. I tried the meatballs as well ...... They where ok, maybe if i grew up in ohio I might think this was a good meatball..... The only thing they had going was clearly thy had spent some time in sauce so they where tender. I have to say take your money and go to Lavo much better italian food.

-itE9-M5Fl8DY3FHiMmn-w.text: I had a larger dinner planned here for a group and it was horrible, especially for the price. First, they told us we would be seated and 15 mins later we weren't with a reservation. The server Nick was horrible. Less than attentive, never checked up on us and at the end when we were still drinking dropped off the check that was prepaid and left. We had to find another waiter up get us drinks.. I guess no effort when you automatically get 18%? The food was subpar. For $85 a person the portions were tiny. The calamari and salad were fine. The pasta was bland and noodles were undercooked. The entrees were tiny to share and not much flavor. The meatballs were average, the lemon chicken had no flavor and the veal was eh. The desserts were ok but again nothing special. With the service and the food I won't ever return here again, especially for a larger event with a preset menu.., way overpriced for the quality.

6iwRELaZjhrN-tCuwO2c9A.text: The ambiance, food and service were fabulous!! Our server, Matt, is as good as it gets. If you have an opportunity to visit, please ask for him...he will definitely keep you coming back. We started with the caprese and the roasted beet salad, both excellent. Followed by the lamb chops and veal chop, both excellent!! With the meal we had an fantastic bottle of Caymus 40th anniversary cab...an excellent value! All in all, a great experience! Would definitely recommend, and we'll be back!

S-HqVG3HXlJWHG40fgCT_g.text: I had a dinner with my boyfriend this past weekend, the food is so delicious, we had lenguine and clams pasta,  also a meatball that the taste was so yummy!  the service was so fast. Little over priced but good food!

kkLyPRsNzBkFUH_oVYiW5w.text: This is down home Italian cooking. Veal parm, eggplant parm, meatballs, etc. It is not cheap but if you want all of your favorites made homemade in a nice setting then this is the place for you. If you think Buca di Beppo is just fine for the price, then probably not your place.

IxngT4PWOpjGwZxH9uzikg.text: FABULOUS FOOD!!!!! Unbelievable flavor and spices!!!!

oKzIFA_8GmXrC9mn_PPw6Q.text: Been to Caesars many times but this was our first visit to Rao's.  Front desk said we'd need to wait a while for a table, so we took immediate seating at he bar. We were glad we  did as Mike provided us with great service.  The food was great as well. I had the scampi and it was served with angel hair pasta.  Good size scampi and good flavor.  Had the cream puff ice cream for dessert and it was incredible.  Overall, a great dinner and time before The Who concert.

pMIJlJvRNKzLDjqwylW9gA.text: Had the Tagliolube with peas and ham. Probably the worse i have ever tasted. My friends veal parmegane tasted like like shoe leather. The equivelant of Olive Garden or less.

1SpsZjydWrARs5HqeJ1rMw.text: Yuck!  Got two pasta dish to go (almost $70 total, most expensive takeout I've ever had) and they definitely did not impress!  Had the tiger shrimp dish of some sort and another penne pasta dish and were both lacklusters. Would not come back even if it were free.

photos.caption: Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States

GZKvezr-TZYosQ3MmsyVHg.text: I was so psyched to dine here but it ended up being a big disappointment.   The food and service was average and the eggplant parm was poor.   I can get better eggplant parm at any pizza joint in New Jersey.   Carmine's would be a better choice. I have dined at Carmine's in NYC and Atlantic City many times and was never disappointed.   OK the meatballs wee good but not that good that everything else can be overlooked.

OhqKcUNDBGmrB8zrNZFGjg.text: The portions are huge, 2 people can definitely share 1 entree.  My husband ordered the beef lasagna which was 5 layers of heaven!  My parents were also dining with us and my mom had the penne vodka.  The noodles were cooked well and the sauce had a lot of flavor.  I had the Caesar salad (it was so hot outside that's all I wanted) which you really can't mess up.  My dad had penne noodles with marina which were also very good.  Only downside, it's pretty pricey.

gTiaAgndkprzt8Pt-x5Eww.text: Rao's has the best meatballs.  I order this as an app and I pretend I'm at the original in NY.  This restaurant has such good energy with the Christmas decorations, pics, and happy employees.

6vZHl_8UwaEKJx3KBy7T3g.text: Amazing food and service. This will be a pricey meal if you go, but save up your money and give it a shot. Definitely one of the best dining experiences I've ever had. We dressed "casual" (I had a button up shirt, shorts and dirty sneakers on) and dined in with no problems in regards to dress code.  I recommend:  Antipasto Meatballs Fusilli w/ Sausage & Cabbage (my favorite) Orecchiette w/ Broccoli Rappe & Sausage

xzDmZJ9JSiZI76kAGsARTw.text: April 25  Decided on dinner at Rao's (pronounced ray-oh's) after viewing their win over Bobby Flay in a Food Network Throwdown focused on who did better Feast of the Fishes.  Quickly seated, I settled on Pasta Fagioli containing Cannellini Beans with Tubetti Pasta and Pecorino Cheese roped with Olive Oil and Chili Flakes to begin. The soup was delicious, heart warming Italian comfort food. Yum!  For the entre, I ordered Ravioli Beggar Purses stuffed with Bartlett Pears and cheese, covered with dried cranberries. Foodgasmand more than filling.  The soup was $15.00, the ravioli was $28.00.  The service was excellent with a busser who was a delight.

nZjOcW-2lTLCndOOVsraug.text: Smashing meatballs, well-made pasta, and great ambiance (gotta love the year-round Christmas decorations!!!!) A little pricey, but the food was VERY good. Skimpy on the portions as far as Italian goes, but nice for a romantic dinner. My few qualms: a wine list that is WAY too pricey (sometimes you just want a $7 glass of wine!) and a waiter who was friendly but completely spaced out and devilishly hard to get a hold of.

EMJpd-ogJ3piLiyMFDmZSA.text: "Meh. I've experienced better" is right.  Nothing personal Rao's, but being a huge fan of Italian food, you were not the best; you weren't even very close, and yes I've had Italian food all over LA, Vegas, and New York.  Don't get me wrong, I absolutely loved the decor and feel of this place, but our server was a little on the pretentious side, as were his recommendations, and the restaurant's pricing. The price you pay for the quality you receive is pretty outrageous, even for Vegas.  Of all the items ordered, the only thing that truly stood out was the meatball everyone talks about. They can sure make a good meatball. But all the pasta dishes were average, the antipasti dish was just okay, and the wine list while decent in selection, was close to double and/or triple what we have paid at other Vegas restaurants, and in New York.   I really wanted to love you. But I'm sorry, my hear belongs to another Italian.

TAVaPgEqIlUJ_lTMnmQHYg.text: First, a lesson. The name of this restaurant does not rhyme with "Wows". It's more like "RAY-Oh's". And now you know. Feel free to click that little "Useful" button down below.  Atmospherically speaking, Rao's is very nice. Warm, clean, inviting. Sort of homey, if you lived in a really nice home. With lots of people eating in it.  Foodwise, Rao's is merely good, in my opinion. The pasta I had was fine, but there wasn't anything to really set it off from a bunch of other Italian restaurants I've been to. And it's pricey too. The average pasta price was around $24. A moderately sized side of spinach was $14. Yes, I realize price around here is as much a factor of location as anything else, but even factoring that in I don't think the price is QUITE justified.   The service was good. Our waitress had good recommendations and water & ice tea glasses were refilled properly.  Something else useful to know (hint, hint) is that while it doesn't say so on the menu, you can get half portions of pasta for a little more ($2 I think) than half the price of the full portion. I made a meal out of two half pastas, and it was enough food. They also give you plenty of bread. My friend's chicken dish was also quite big. If you aren't super hungry you could probably split an appetizer and an entree between two people, which would make Rao's a bit more affordable.  I'm a little torn between 3 & 4 stars, but at the end of the day I'm not ready to call myself a fan.

8HZC53kM9khqIpLh3WJ5fw.text: Must be as good as New York location because meal was great, I don't know for sure because I can't get a reservation. Meatball appetizer and lemon chicken where fantastic!

ldr2M07xVVLHmSsQAVynrA.text: One of the best Italian restaurants I've eaten at. The potions are comparable for the price, and the service is second to none.   This is the second time my wife and I have eaten here and definitely wasn't a let down. I highly recommend the meatball appetizer as well as the lasagna. My wife ordered the stuffed shells, which were also great!   If I could give 6 stars, I definitely would have! Please keep in mind that you need to make a reservation....

ZXMs7GkEcOTzYPqx7gWACw.text: Try the meatballs, that is the best item on the menu! I was here for an after party so I did not get to enjoy the full menu but they have an awesome patio space with a great  view of the pool. Also, the cannolis are pretty good. Definitely have to go back for a regular dinner.

mnJz2qZcwh3hB9IrFALssw.text: Food was on point in the True Rao's traditions. Service is as good as it gets and waiter Russel treated us with great respect while he played happy birthday to me on his Kazoo! What an exciting dinner. Thank you Rao's.

Sg1QYvfTyvpkph9iarI5tg.text: Service - our waitress was great.  Friendly and informative, not phony and was honest and available when needed.  I feel bad for her as she is not responsible for the fact the restaurant lacks the basics for a really good Italian restaurant.  Decor - good view of the pool from our table a bit dark but overall decent atmosphere  Food/Drink - someone is getting cheap on the wine.  When you order a glass of wine that costs $17, you expect at least a good pour.  I felt like they poured the final remains of a bottle and didn't want to open another.  I felt cheated.  The bread/crispy lavish cheesy things were good.  Their meatballs were yummy.  Vodka and cream sauce penne was just ok.  Linguini & clams was awful.  I know it's seafood but when you bite into a bowl of this dish, it tasted like the ocean.  I have had this dish dozens of times but this one I could not eat.  It was too spicy like cracked pepper spicy and it was "fishy"  I have never not finished a plate linguini and this one I just could not stomach.  Thank goodness the waitress was kind enough to take the charge off of our bill.  We are not ones to complain too much so that is why we didn't speak up originally about this dish.  Dessert - Tiramisu was yummy.  As we walked out, a nice big roach was crawling across the carpet.  Nothing worse than seeing one of these critters actually where people are dining as you know there are probably more in the back.  I know restaurants have a hard time controlling this but to see it in the actual restaurant made me lose my appetite.  I guess expect more especially at a place that charges this much for ok to sub-standard food.

5AvIdj2IyV0q6axoP2oa5A.text: The 2 things I rate a restaurant is their service and their food.. then the decor and so on.. the service I received walking in was quick. Which I loved. The host is usually your first impression of a restaurant. If I don't like it then I just walk out. Angela which was my server was quick to come to my table to introduce herself. I asked her a few questions about the menu since it was my first time and she gave me her advice. I got the Shrimp and lobster pasta which she recommended and let me tell you... I loved it. The portions are big and it's a really good price. I asked her advice on a good wine to company the food and I was so happy. I would definitely recommend Raos if you want to eat good and be full. I was sad that I ate so much I wasn't able to try the desert but I plan to come back on my next visit to Vegas. Thanks to everyone in the restaurant that made my experience so wonderful. Oh and love the decor and music.

photos.caption: Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_nslsPPGMgrucKDLJNp9mA.text: We went here for my husband's 30th birthday dinner. The staff was friendly and attentive, and gave great recommendations for food. I had the chicken scarpariello, and it was seriously the most delicious chicken I've ever had! My hubby had the linguine and clams, and thoroughly enjoyed it as well. We had the profiteroles for desert, and they were perfect! I want to go back to Las Vegas again just to eat here! It's a little pricey, but well worth it for a celebration!

7gk90DuZqshayqwUVQlTVQ.text: The food was good, the service was great.  Our server was very attentive and nice. Had a couple of decent glasses of wine to start and the bruschetta. Decent but nothing to get excited about. My wife had the special Chicken Parm and I had the special Salmon. We both agreed they were good but not great. My Salmon was a bit salty. For an Italian restaurant I expected to hear some good old Italian music.  Instead the place had hard rock playing; that seemed odd. The hostess was a bit cold because we didn't have reservations. The place never got more than half full throughout our stay. Probably won't come back as the options in Vegas are a plenty.

RBrET5IG5pTuJJHxlly2sQ.text: I've never eaten at an Olive Garden.  If Rao's had been one, I would have walked out with a couple of hundred dollars more in my pocket, and said it was okay.  But grading on a price to dining experience ratio, not so much.  Look, I know that every restaurant at Caesar's Palace is overpriced, and I'm perfectly willing to overpay for a great dinner, but this was overpaying for a mediocre dinner.  We started with Frito Misto for the table.  A couple of bites convinced me to save my appetite for the next course.  It's not that it was bland.  It had flavor.  It's just that it had flavors I didn't care for.  So on to the first course special - Pasta Fagioli.  Dean Martin claims that this dish should make me drool like I'm in love, but it was pretty much just a bowl of soup.  My main course was the bone-in veal parm, which was huge.  That made it a bit of a waste, since I left most of it on the plate, and declined an offer to take the rest home in a doggy bag.  I knew I could whip up something for tomorrow night's dinner that would taste much better.   I also had a side of Quattro Fromagi pasta - large pasta shells with no noticeable cheese flavor and, come to think of it, no particular flavor at all.  In short, I just wasn't impressed. Neither was the rest of our table.  My wife had a pasta dish, which she described as "acceptable."  One of our friends had chicken, which he called "a waste."  Our other friend had a steak, on which he didn't comment.  The room was a bit cramped.  The walls were completely covered with photographs of people who, I guess, you had to be a New Yorker to recognize.  I certainly didn't.  Service was attentive, but a bit rushed.  The goal seemed to be quick turnaround of the table, rather than facilitating a relaxing dining experience.  So the whole thing was disappointing.  If my veal parm had cost $22, I probably wouldn't have minded leaving most of it on the plate.  But at $53 I expected something top notch.  This wasn't it.  My suggestion:  If you want a high-end and fairly priced Italian meal, go a mile off the strip to Piero's Italian Cuisine.

2U5B7aL86ZVM7SQ3LVbssQ.text: Had the meatballs only and they were amazing.. Service was quick and the bartender asked if i would like something to drink while i wait! Place is very cool looking, i will come here for a full meal the next time but had to try the meatballs and they were SUPER GOOD!

bqWx8XfuYwWhG3pshItawQ.text: This is hands down my favorite Italian restaurant and I make sure to come here whenever I'm in Vegas (you can't get into the one in New York). Everything is superb. I recently had veal Milanese, which I'm still drooling about days later. From beginning to end it's a great dining experience!

XpFFEvtZ_fBMgcCBi8zspQ.text: Seriously, the hospitality, food, ambiance and cocktails are the best in town. Love coming here!

fdWetTadcjYsViR571AYaA.text: If you are going to eat Italian in Vegas this is the only place to go. Old school feel, amazing vibe and the food is authentic as it gets. I could eat the Raos meatball almost daily. Add a glass of wine and it makes for the perfect night on the strip!

cwNOQ7ZHaSCO0BHYx_Qhog.text: Rao's may not win big points for creating the most imaginative dishes or the most powerful flavors but it makes for where it counts with really consistent, solid food that is worth eating all-around!    The coworkers and I went family style - sharing several fine dishes.  The giant meatball side (you get 2) could be it's own meal.  Topped with some Parmesan cheese, the meatballs are excellent.  We also got a special - a linguini pasta with crab and a light fettucini/olive oil sauce.  The clams as well were delicious - a little on the smaller side but full of flavor and baked to perfection.  The food amount for the most part nearly worked out too - hitting the middle ground for a good-sized portion for sharing or eating alone.  Additionally, you get a bunch of different types of bread like olive bread to a cracker that you can dip in your own olive oil/balsamic vinaigrette!  We ended the meal with profiteroles that were drenched in chocolate sauce - it was a great finish.  The price for all of these dishes ended up about $50 per person - not too shabby when you think about the amount of food we were hitting up.  The server was super super friendly and the staff were diligent about refilling water and taking away plates after they were done.  The seating we had was nice as well - right by the pool that in the Winter was closed and made for a nice, serene view.  Seating seems pretty plentiful as well as a nice middle circle bar.  To find Rao's, it'll be deeper into the Casino by the Bacchanal and a sushi stand (as well as a dessert place across the way).     Rao's isn't the best Italian I've ever bad but it sure is plentiful and tasty enough to just make you enjoy yourself in Vegas.  The prices aren't exorbitant and you feel like you're being treated well.  If you're looking for Italian and a nice place on the Strip, Rao's is solid all-around.

0g_x9-80VqIdCdLhRAf1Nw.text: This is one of my favorite old school restaurant. Top quality food. Amazing meatballs and pastas. Feels your back in Italy. Must try.

iRbFrQUr6EDLuDbh0AUYiw.text: Service from staff was good and the only reason I give a 2nd star. While staff was attentive food was not only overpriced but a "spicy" lobster/shrimp dish they had was pretty bland - over cooked shrimp, sauce tasted watered-down, and pasta was overcooked. Atmosphere wasn't a great impression because the "outside courtyard" setting wasn't outside but rather inside a lobby area with a bar which meant rowdy people.

rPpRshS2La2rH1EYCcGOnw.text: Great place to eat and relax. Customer service was awesome! I will be back for another visit!

Q5X88zgeK3B2TRIOvT5JGw.text: One of the best Italian restaurants in Las Vegas.  We ordered quite a few dishes and here are the favorites:   Meatballs - excellent taste and very pleasing.   Veal Parm on the bone - fantastic hands down.   Shrimp scampi with angel hair pasta was also very yummy.   Finally the penne a la vodka was pretty good.   I wasn't impressed with the tiramisu or the cannoli. I've had much better at restaurants in NY.   Nonetheless one great restaurant and worth the visit

AhlsW6zTkZqYAgNMe6M0oQ.text: This was the second time eating here and the food was wonderful.  We had a group of 6 and everyone got something different.  I have one friend who is a vegetarian and got the RAVIOLI PURSES it was really good that one of the other guys said he would have ordered it.  I am a big fan of the meatballs and split an order with one of the guys.  Our group after drinking for a little while decided to play credit card roulette.  Our waitress got us a basket to pick the cards and I lucked out and got a free dinner.  I think this will be a staple on my Las Vegas trips.

_gKj7tPq1iLmkyTbhv51lA.text: Nice, Italian ambiance with an obvious selection of traditional meals. Prices are inline with what I have come to expect for Vegas - you're going to pay a premium for things you're used to eating. I had the ossobuco over risotto and it was amazingly tender and flavorful. I accompanied the meal with a house Cabernet Sauvignon. Delicious.

TMCz-5d12uztf0ZKCxaVoQ.text: 3.5 stars! The host in the front was a little rude but overall the experience wasnt so bad.  We needed to find a place to eat before a show so Raos was the only one able to take in a party of 9 in short notice but there wasnt a line or something so you can see why. The service was average and our waiter seem annoyed with us or something but in the end he was nicer.  The food was average for me. We ordered the lemon chicken and it was good but not that flavorful, the mashed potatoes are to die for though. Taste like its from scratch and buttery! Also you have to try the side of meat balls! You get 2 huge meat balls in sauce and they are very good and moist.

HeoMy1egzyFSXOAAOrIRhg.text: The vibe & food were awesome. Especially the food though. They have a delicious red pepper butter & their penne vodka is one (if not the) best I've ever had. We're vegetarians and we felt like they had a good variety for us. It's a hefty price tag but the food is definitely worth it. Will go again once were back in Vegas.

yUEy6E6FQKDQuHKUtqqsTw.text: Glad we stopped in. Great service and amazing food! A little pricy but what can you expect when you dine on the strip.

Kr5NabUb8EViYIqv_umpNA.text: When first arriving, after the host found my reservation, I was directed to my table near the center bar area. Once seated, our waiter knew from the reservation that I would be seeing a show inside of the Colosseum. She sat down next to my table and pulled up a chair. She was genuinely nice and wanted to make sure my dinner experience was the best it could be. She asked a few key food questions. After that, an on the spot custom menu was created by pointing out exactly what I would enjoy.   She correctly picked the calamari for the first course. It came with excellent marinara sauce.  The second course was an arugula salad with pear strips, candied walnuts and parmesan cheese shavings.   The third and final tasty course was the 17 oz perfectly cooked NY Strip Steak. It was crusted on the side via spices and olive oil. The steak was juicy through to the last piece.   Thanks to Caesar's Palace for making the arrangements for dinner before I went to go see a show in the Colosseum. I had not visited Rao's before that night for a complete dinner, but I had been there for an event with small appetizers and mini desserts.  I recommend this restaurant to anyone who wants a delicious steak, calamari (which is difficult to cook correctly) and a light salad.

JiRZulSBVleFdqmSK_h6xg.text: Pasta is always solid. Always cooked to perfection. The Garlic, broccoli fusilli was fantastic. I don't care for the meatballs. Their sauces are amazing. The chicken scarapariello is delicious. The desserts are just average.

tbrGRjRxD6hSK4174_ariw.text: Went to Rao's with my wife. It was as good as advertised. She had chicken marsala and I had short ribs. The first course was huge, and delicious, for both of us. She had the Caesar salad and I had the seafood appetizer of calamari, shrimp and cod. The first course was big enough to be the main course. Next visit I want to try the old school Italian food like lasagna or the spaghetti and meatballs. We'll be back.

8VIbVMAiu3pQvrlbcigW1g.text: Great place! I was staying at Caesars. I had no plans to eat there but was pacing buy and thought we would try it out. Originally we went in just for a drink and some appetizers, but it was so good ended up staying for dinner. Great place, reasonable prices, considering it's Vegas and everything is expensive.

3PGYiOqebbjL0_IMAb0mWw.text: Went to Rao's before the Celine Dion concert.  Pricey, but well worth it.  I had the scampi, boyfriend had the clams.  Everything from the service to the food was excellent!!  I'll be back.

VDZy-pyUMl8sYWb2mhRydw.text: Very good food and service! I loved the Chicken Cacciatore! So tasty and they made it gluten free, too!  Don't miss this great Italian restaurant.

h4nUNaHi6zpVJN72jA9_RA.text: This is a great place that is in the heart of the casino. I appreciated the service and high quality food. This place has become a hub of entertainment and eateries. A nice mix.

L4epYCpxUNC4sNXt-zpDJg.text: The first time was great. The next 3 visits a disaster! Food has gone way down in quality. Horrible steak on visit #2 and the clams got us sick on our last visit. Not to mention the lack of attention from the waiter. At the prices they charge the service should be fabulous and friendly. That it was not!  If you must...the calamari and the meatballs are good.

WLBtqvvSyUw-UoKvbNR6rw.text: ined on 4/39/11. We live in LV, so hubs took us there for anniversary. Food was really good, wine avg $18 per glass, meatballs (1 side dish, two small fist sized meat balls) $15. Purse ravioli was yummy and hubs loved the bolognase sauce. Dinner was a little over $200 for 2 peeps. Ambiance was issue - very loud music, large and loud tables, could barely understand waiter, felt like I was in a diner as opposed to "expensive" restaurant - attire is very casual, flip flops and shorts on most patrons on a sat night, so that kinda ruined it too. For the price I shouldn't have to yell across the table and the cash man photo lady came while I was eating my appetizer and was loud and a little pushy - 2 5*7 photos are $40.  I would return, but not for an elegant meal

eBFy1zPk8U-PvlWe0OgADQ.text: The fried calamari appetizer was amazing. The lamb chops and veal chop were super tender and delicious. Desserts were great. The tiramisu and the Oreo cake were pretty large, but went well with an Irish coffee. Avoid the peach crisp. Pretty pricy, but hey, it's the Strip.

A7qvkc4Sd6fZjx_qxa5ljQ.text: Terrible Terrible Terrible. Wait staff put us in the back by the entrance to the rear eating space. Table was behind the bar near a crowd of about 40 people. Whats worse is that the entire restaurant was half empty.  Waiter seemed nice but took 20 minutes to come over. Appetizers were worse than your favorite Pizza Place's Italian Food. The bread was your typically Italian hard bread, nothing special. Canceled the entrees but the manager had no problem clearing the bill completely when we asked to leave. Gave us a business card on the way out, wont be coming back.

5SqyreMKu63qOIX2JHNA1Q.text: Perfect meatballs.  Everything I have had is the best!!  The antipasti salad is a must order for the table.  It serves four to five people. You can't go wrong here. Hands down best Italian food ever at Rao's.

baKr1cKJCRv0BHSkvoobdQ.text: I was treated to dinner one night here, and was very impressed with everything about it. My water glass was always full, my wine seemed to be bottomless - from the time we walked up (without reservation) we did not have to wait for anything besides dinner itself. Per the recommendation of my dinner companion he suggested the stuffed shells for our entree and for our appetizer I ordered (my favorite) caprese salad, it was fresh, creamy and delicious. Once our entree came out, I agreed with my companion that the sauce smelt fantastic! We enjoyed as much as we possibly could of this creamy, basil filled, stuffed shells dish before we had to ask the waiter to wrap our leftovers. Wine was great, service was attentive and friendly, food was great. Worth it.

uxOY2fGewh6zYvGtU8uVpQ.text: We came here without reservations on a Friday night. We walked up to the VERY snooty hostess and asked how long the wait was? Her response in a very bitchy manner "we are all booked for the evening." Funny b/c we looked around and there were quite a few empty tables. So we continued to ask her, is there anyway you could squeeze us in (yes we were hungry and didn't want to go searching for another place we could all agree on!). Again she just gave us a snooty "no."   My friend decided to take a walk in the back of the restaurant by the bar and saw a friendly waiter who told us that we could sit anywhere in the bar - open seating. SO why didn't the biatch in the front tell us that? We immediately found a table and sat. I was a little disappointed in the vegetarian options. I got the special of the day (some sort of ravioli with mushrooms and spinach). I didn't love it. One of my friends really liked her vodka pasta dish. The other girl in the group had to send her pasta dish back b/c it was way to Al Dente.   Overall, over priced food, huge portions of pasta, but nothing special about the taste.

HQvL_MaTRfa8PKpG_dNVxg.text: Just spent an intimate dinner with friends. We enjoyed an unrushed, 3 hour dinner that was spectacular.  George served us and if I ever go back again, I'll ask for him.  The creme brulee was very good, the meatballs were slightly smaller than softball-sized and delicious, and the clam linguini was outstanding (perfect al dente pasta and the white wine sauce was amazing.)  The crowd was a little loud but not so much that we couldn't talk.  I recommend this place and will be back when I can afford it!  (The restroom was clean as I expected and couldn't help notice the health dept solid "A" grades.)

_gwz7mObgbLKWBOc0iIZ7w.text: Had dinner there last week ...... went there with great anticipation because of its legendary status in New York ....... mildly disappointing but easily correctable .... the place itself is fun ... its old-timey Italian restaurant decor with all the celeb photos hung on wall ... very professional and most attentive service...... good food but not great ...... seems like the kitchen is trying to '' play it safe'' and the result is a very ample portion of just slightly above average entrees ...... my veal dish was good but not as good as I had hoped based on the Rao's reputation ( hype ? ) .... so they have a nice,fun setting,great servers and decent offerings but if they really got into that kitchen and tweaked their prep a bit ...... they'd improve on a product that is just a tad on the bland side. I hope they address this as it is a fun restaurant with good personnel .

3MWcK4RdH9Bz_AbcN2fP0g.text: I'm surprised at the negativity of some of the reviews below.  The common theme in the reviews is that this restaurant is crazy expensive.  Hello -- welcome to Vegas!  Even the frickin' Starbucks have marked up their prices in Vegas.  Doesn't that tell anyone beside me anything?  Okay, and so once you 'get' that things are pricier in Vegas, how does Rao's do?  Firstly, I don't know the NYC location.  Never heard of this 'chain' until I stumbed upon this Vegas location.  What made our experience special --  -- is that we were initially sat in the inner room, with the dark booths -- a vintage flavored Eyetalian restaurant.  If I had been sat more outside in the cafe area, I'm convinced I wouldn't have enjoyed it as much.  Next I had the only waiter I've ever asked the name of and requested on returns trips.  Yup -- I won't eat at this place unless I'm inside and being served by this dude.  Really nice guy.  Won't give his name or I may jam up my little secret hideaway.  Next up is the bread they drop on the table.  Hello.  My God niece's jaw dropped like a rock when that hit the table.  She's a carb addict and was in instant heaven.  I was in heaven watching her in heaven.  So then we order.  It doesn't matter exactly what we ordered because everything is essentially the same quality here:  somewhere between B+ to an A-.  To get an A or A+, they'd have to serve uniquely distinctive dishes with bigger portions.  But they don't because they're taking the french bistro 'less is more' thing instead of the old school 'giant portions of mediocrity'.   So the clam pasta was good, but not amazing.  The manicotti solid but not stunning.  The gnocchi definitely tasty but not ambrosia.  Understand, I tried the Onda Italian restaurant inside the Mirage.  Similar prices.  Food is between B- to B+.  But the windowless big room prohibitively claustrophobic -- as in, why sit here unless in a hurry? Service okay but not as enthusiastic as Caesar's.  CPK inside the Mirage probably offers the best value of all three places, but you're sitting IN the casino with all the thick cheesy cigarette smoke.    So what is so terrible about Rao's again?   Not much.  They claimed the gnocchi were made fresh, but I'm not buying that.  The clams were tiny in the pasta, but voluminous, and the sauce with subtle and spicy.  If I were the manager of this place, I'd make the menu much smaller but everything simply amazing.  I'd use the Tao restaurant as a guide.    But I've been told the Tao owners opened an Italian joint in Palazzo, called Lavo.  Guess what?  No, go ahead, guess.  That's right -- Yelpers say it's only so-so and way over-priced.  Get it?  Got it?  Good.  Enjoy.  UPDATE:  Had the Shrimp Scampi here.  A simply sinful ball of pasta with four BIG shrimp on top.  Not only my new favorite here, but with the Sea Bass at the TAO probably one of the favorite dishes in Vegas (so far).

GOF40ygsaDmSXP9GfqgwDw.text: The pasta was decadent and delicious! I had the pasta carbonara which was on the specials menu for the day. It was creamy and the pasta was cooked perfectly al dente. The salmon was also perfectly cooked, but the quinoa that came with it was bland. A must try is the calamari appetizer. The calamari is so soft I've never had any like it. The service though was on the slow side. My husband had to walk to the bar to get a second drink as we could not get a hold of our waiter to get another one.

photos.caption: Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States

WkE2GMEuCuNQ8vHP0B8c8A.text: 5 stars for the food, 1 star for the ambiance. I've never been so happy to leave a restaurant. The service wasn't bad, but when I'm spending $30-$50 per entree I expect a little more. The staff was so stiff and stale it left me feeling uncomfortable, and ultimately unwelcome. I don't think I saw a single person smile in that restaurant.  Especially not the 2 hostesses that stared at me upon my arrival. No hello or welcome was given. The worst part was when the bill came, our server and both hostesses seemed to be standing over our table, as if we were planning on skipping out on the check. I was uncomfortable, but once my mom pointed out the odd behavior I knew it was time to leave.    Needless to say, I will not be returning to Rao's and more importantly I will not recommend it to any friends, family, guests, or tourists I encounter.

saiHzucp1pnfGeqRJl0reA.text: We ordered their meatballs, lasagna, and the penne with vodka sauce. The meatballs were so moist and incredible. Our waiter described how they are made first by pan frying them with olive oil and then baking them in the oven with half marinara sauce and half water to allow both the steam and the heat to cook the meatballs from inside out.  The penne with vodka sauce is just how I imagined it and uses their world-famous vodka sauce to do it! This is truly an experience! Ask for extra vodka sauce if you order this!  The lasagna is also soft and moist! It's really hard to describe how perfect the flavors blend together as well as how the pasta is cooked. It was really great.  The overall service was perfect! They took care of my party and met all of our needs. They even described the room and pictures in the room that is the exact replica of the one in New York! He also described the outside of the restaurant and how it replicates the one in New York with the two street signs that are perpendicular to the restaurant as well as how the view would look in front of it!  People were dressed casually in shorts while others were dressed in business casual. Overall, a great dinner to have in Vegas!

OVGoHromxNlpHSR49A85FA.text: I'm seriously irritated about the $26 shrimp cocktail that had 5 or 6 2 inch shrimp.  Usually if you are going to put a price that high for shrimp cocktail the shrimp are going to be massive.  The service was good until the end where the weighted disappeared for 20 minutes.  On a plus side the lasagna melts in your mouth and is outstanding.

-42kXFSZq8mnmHdAuUVgnQ.text: In my top two or three things to do when I'm in Vegas. A bit pricey, oh, but the food. Oh my God, it is wonderful. My wife and I have tried 6 different items, all have been terrific. Very fair portions, but as I said, a bit pricey. Figure on $75 + per person. As a once in a while splurge, well worth it. Give it a try, you'll look forward to a return trip.

Cs2pSbVHyAnd2DB641P4zA.text: When I asked the waiter if this was as good as the orginal he said it is 90% close. He probably meant to say 65 % close. I have been waiting a long time to eat at Rao but unfortunately I find myself in Las Vegas instead of New York. Overall the restaurant is good,  with a great atmosphere and good food. The lobster linguini and the veal steak stood out, however the rest was good if not hinging on ok. These days great Italian food is found every where (especially Vegas) so if an Italian restaurant wants to stand out you probably need to be be outstanding. Maybe my expectations were set too high.  Looking forward to trying the orginal.

s3vuL31J2jTjKLizCk_Enw.text: This is my second visit to this restaurant and I really enjoy it. The antipasto and baked clams were super good. The atmosphere is extremely inviting with all of the old photos on the wall and great music playing. We will definitely return.

E7dICPzhRzRG4MYsazVDOQ.text: Great service; good food.  The service was fantastic and made the meal feel worth the price. The food was tasty, the fried green tomato caprese was good and was not greasy.  The quattro formaggi was the deluxe equivalent to mac n cheese; worth ordering imo.  The tiramisu was just ok, it was average and nothing special.

JFdVl7GBxvkwq7ri6-JOCQ.text: Such a disappointment! Never eat in an empty restaurant on a Friday night in Vegas! The service was good, food was horrible.   I had the veal parm, tasted like cardboard and cause was very tangy. I sent it back and got a pasta dish which was almost just as bad. My wife and I ended up not finishing our dishes. The highlight was the meatball appetizer.

W4co5LEZdLdXDJs8LrXoDg.text: The food was great but the portions were pretty small. I enjoyed the purse ravioli, very flavorful and unique. I recommend bringing a light sweater because it was kind of cold in the restaurant.

VGtRKQYSnYQC5IiQUC2p6Q.text: We love Rao's. It is always one of our stops in Vegas. This year we went for a regular meal & went back for Thanksgiving. Matt, our waiter, was his wonderfully ebullient self making our experience all the better.   Our non-holiday night started with meatballs. Why had we not had this before? On the first bite angels sang. I nearly cancelled the Osso Buco for more meatballs. The braised veal shank with saffron risotto always pleases the palate, but the meatballs!  I highly recommend both.  On other visits we have had the veal scallopini (with marsala), ravioli purses, chicken saltimbocca and a few others over the years. We have loved every dish.   Rao's also made special vegetable dishes for us. Grilled fennel anyone? Magnificent.   I will be back & will request Matt again.

AcWkANQMScj_u0ED17L9Vg.text: 3.5 stars Met up with a couple friends here because this was their favorite Italian place to hit up every time they're in Vegas. Only heard nothing but good things about Rao's from the Food Network and on an episode of the Travel Channel's The Best Of, so I was stoked to finally get a chance to check it out. Unfortunately, the head chef (ex-wife of the Rao's owner) Carla Pelligrino no longer runs the kitchen. I think that might've had something to do with some of the lackluster dishes we were served that night. Of course my boys and I had to get liquored up on some bread and booze while waiting for our appetizers. Alcohol is pricey, but expected when you're in Vegas. What I didn't expect was how little alcohol was detected in our mixed drinks: - 2008 Chianti Classico Cecchi ($55) - Dirty Vodka Martini ($15.50) - Grey Goose Pear Martini ($13) - Chilled Belvedere Vodka shots ($12.50) The cracker bread was the best part of the bread basket. Everything else seemed stale. yelp.com/biz_photos/KkmP... BRUSCHETTA (4 pcs for $17): Thinly sliced crunchy crostinis topped off with 1) Tomato & Basil: Needed a touch of salt and some acid 2) Marinated Artichokes: My piece still had the inedible fibrous hairy part of "choke" still intact. Not very lady-like of me to have to spit this out in front of the hot waiter walking by. Ugh. yelp.com/biz_photos/KkmP... RAO'S MEATBALLS (side order of 2 fist-sized meatballs for $16): The first thing people mention when talking about Rao's is their famous traditional meatballs served with their house marinara sauce. Combining the right ratio of ground veal, pork and lean beef with pecorino cheese makes it oh-so flavorful and meaty! My only complaint was that it was a bit on the dry side. Thank goodness for the marinara sauce! yelp.com/biz_photos/KkmP... ORECCHIETTE CON BROCCOLI RAPPE (sweet italian sausage, broccoli rabe and garlic sauteed in extra virgin olive oil, $26): I enjoyed the sweet italian sausage very much. The casing had a fantastic bite to it, while the sausage itself remained oh-so-juicy and seasoned perfectly. yelp.com/biz_photos/KkmP... Everything else was not up to par: 1) The orecchiette pasta was undercooked. There were a bunch of them still stuck in hard undercooked clusters of 2 or 3 pieces. Imagine every forkful being hard and chewy. 2) The broccoli rabe was so damn bitter that it threw off the entire dish. I LOVE broccoli rabe, it's bitterness is what makes it unique. But this was the first time I've had it overpower an entire dish. ***A quick 1 min blanch prior to throwing it into the pasta would've saved this dish*** SPAGHETTI ALLA BOLOGNESE ($27): Ground beef, pork and veal (same mixture and tastes as their meatballs) cooked with San Marzano Tomatoes and herbs. These particular plum tomatoes are less acidic and sweeter when compared to the usual Roma tomatoes used by most Italian places, so I could see how Rao's chose this for their tasty marinara and bolognese sauce. Would've been a perfect dish if it weren't for the overcooked pasta. RIGATONI FILETTO DI POMODORO (pancetta, sweet white onions and lots of black pepper, $25): The same same San Marzano tomato sauce was used. The rigatoni was undercooked. But I could forgive that since there was a good amount of pancetta in the sauce. Served with a light dusting of pecorino cheese, we asked for extra cheese to cover the entire dish, lol! This pasta dish needed the extra saltiness from the pecorino cheese, trust.

photos.caption: Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bruschetta ($17): fresh tomatoes, basil, extra virgin olive oil &amp; marinated artichokes
Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Love the complimentary bread: raisin, olive and cheese lavash
Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Traditional Rao&#39;s Meatballs in tomato sauce ($16): a must!!

y3FuL4ACjEG5mtdrITOxcg.text: I had the pleasure of dining at Rao's while in LV on business. Rao's as a strong reputation to live up to and considering it is just about impossible to reserve a table at their NYC location I was looking forward to dining here.  I arrived for an early dinner with a colleague and we elected to dine on their patio (people watching is great at Caesars Palace) so we did not get to experience the NYC style restaurant inside. Right up front service was fantastic. Our server was very knowledgeable regarding the chef specials, their wine, and very patient and agreeable as we customized our entrees.   From start to finish the food was exceptional. Start off with fresh bread and their homemade butter while you attempt to pair down your dinner choices. I opted for the Caesar salad with fresh cheese and extra anchovies. My dining companion's caprese salad is a great choice as well.  I selected the linguine and clam sauce with white sauce. The clams were small Manila clams. The dish was spiced with, noticeable, garlic, white wine, & red pepper. After devouring my dinner I finished off the wonderful sauce with their bread. Absolutely exceptional!  My dining companion had the Bolognese with penne pasta she reported bliss as well.  Rao's is indeed pricey but well worth it if you care to experience a wonderful traditional Italian fare.

QiHqcQmNh9AVYMypGEQXeA.text: This was not my first time at Rao's. As usual, the service was very good. Unfortunately, the food was not as good as previous visits. The portions appeared much smaller. Our pasta bolognese was extremely dry. The rest of our dishes were just ok. We used to think the food was incredible and worth the price but not anymore.

wjdfKhAUbrsR_U5rQitLJA.text: Having been at the original Rao's twice in New York City, I didn't want to come here and compare the two because I knew it would be night and day. But i would up doing it anyway. The first thing is the Meatballs. While most will never get to experience them in New York, I will tell you there is no better. Anywhere. Here they were fine. Way overpriced but fine. Ordered the Lemon Chicken that they are famous for. Almost as good as the original but just off. Mozzerella in Corroza was close to the least tasty I have had anywhere. Pasta was perfectly Al Dente and the red sauce was better then average. To many choices here in Vegas. Won't make a special trip to return.

O6E7Ulu0yk7WmT4P5Hfv-A.text: Outstanding!    Every time we come to Vegas, we visit Rao's; it delivers consistently. My wife cooks a lot of the meals out of their cook books and the consistency here is amazing.   I've had a number of meals here. The Lemmon Chicken is a standout.  Last time around, I had the chicken with sausage and veggies. Amazing.  Service has always been excellent. The staff in general is always friendly. The restaurant is decorated in a similar fashion to the one in NYC according to staff.  Tables and booths are comfy.  There's ample seating to absorb a pretty good crowd.   On our last visit, we had the opportunity to meet and hang out with the owners.  It was an awesome experience.

ibVCMQ9TxZxB_EROHZYyrQ.text: Ate at the bar and it was great but expensive.  Best Caprese salad ever and finished it off with veal Parmesan.  Veal parm was served bone in and the best I've had ever.  The server did an amazing job-- excellent service!!

N0Em8u4x6iQnaNr-bxB5Iw.text: Lives up to the hype!!! From the wine, meat balls, Penne vodka, peanut butter tart to Renee. Wonderful experience. Highly recommend.
