qEZ3fCi41Fdpzg-lQrhOGA.text: Great food, large portions. The meatballs really are delicious! Only complaint would be the corner we were sitting in was very dark.

bqFpIE6tUSdaZi7he4Ouag.text: The ravioli purses are arguably my favorite italian dish ever. My last name ends in a vowel so that is saying a lot. I have been here three times and it is the only dish I have ever ordered because it is so good. The bread and butter they serve prior to your entrees is great. The butter is like non other and has a distinct flavor. The scenery throughout the restaurant is very nice and is a True italian feel.   The service was okay, which is normal for me being in my mid twenties in an upscale place.   The portions here are very generous and you can usually take some of it back to your hotel room and have yourself a very rich 2:00 am snack after a night of drinking.   Rao's is one of my favorite restaurants in Vegas. It's also way easier to get into compared to the NYC location.

J1g0fXS4ai7c-2YBqM6dBg.text: We have enjoyed a lot of amazing meals in Las Vegas over the years, including this last trip. This was not one of them. This was our first time trying Rao's. We have been wanting to try it in New York, but we are not celebrities so that's never going to happen. On this trip we decided to use one of our precious evenings for dinner here to finally try it out. I cannot tell you how incredibly disappointing it was. The minute we walked in and were seated I had a bad feeling. The room we were in was extremely claustrophobic, loud, and just didn't smell very clean. I had to shout to talk to my husband. The service was average at best, nothing more than you would get in any kind of a chain restaurant. But the food was the real problem. We started with the meatballs. I grew up eating pasta and meatballs, and I know good red sauce. The meatballs themselves were okay.  Not amazing but not awful. The sauce was not good, bland, and that pretty much ruined the appetizer. I did not even finish mine and that says a lot. Let's not forget the bread. The bread itself was nothing special at all. -  just OK, but the large crackers in the bread basket were terrible. They literally tasted like stale saltines. I tried the ravioli purses and they were actually not bad. I will give them three stars. I would have to have them again but they were just average - nothing I would ever seek out. On the other hand, my husband had spaghetti Bolognese and it was pretty terrible. It was a massive bowl of pasta with substandard sauce. I tasted it and frankly, pasta that's not fresh out of the box tastes as good if not better. It was a massive letdown. Quantity does not make up for quality. I will happily pay more than $30 a dish for GOOD pasta but this was overpriced trash. For dessert we tried the profiteroles, something we have had before many times elsewhere. The pastry was gross, not fresh, dry, hard to eat even. I didn't finish mine. For me not to finish dessert is unheard of. I would say the only good thing about this meal was that I tried it and I am no longer curious, and maybe that I did not leave feeling like I overate! Give it a skip.

Q-7EDOxGyo1xTpApVbG8qQ.text: It's good, alright? Some guy, black shirt not our waiter, I think his name was Frankie? Super knowledgeable about the history of Rao. It's good Italian American. A bit too salty which is what they need to do for commercial approval. Whatever. That's it. One bite everyone knows the rules.

p5g-cjqjj8axX4pNf2SmMw.text: The meatballs were not the the beat but decent.  The burrata salad was small but the cheese was perfection.   Bartender was honest and friendly.

4We8Xr4ilkNjAqdQ1_szjw.text: Came here during a work event, didn't have a lot of time to eat but the antipasto was amazing, and who couldn't pass up that it was national wine that day as well, really bummed i didn't get to try any of their other dishes but this one was awesome

q-bd6B9M-pVFWm-1qZv4Pw.text: Get the lasagna. The ambiance and food were perfect. Staff friendly too. We asked the server for recommendations. He said the lasagna is a favorite and he was spot on.

vnZJiphjqV38uDX0YB705w.text: Read the reviews before eating here....if this is the best Italian Vegas has to offer they are in need of more restaurants. I ordered the chicken scarpariello. It was lacking in any flavor. The service was great and very pleasant...the only reason they got any stars I suppose.

IxMUpQek-SEMHc5nHKFxag.text: Exceeded expectations. A beautiful restaurant with delicious food. A nice quiet haven in the chaos of Vegas. Highly recommend.

Qav8JYwVizOjMDqhpPyHcA.text: My favorite dish is the Fruti di mare. Nice ambiance, best sauces no matter what you order

kAoPcQ-sgrG6BYD9k7dRqw.text: Angela didn't seem to want to be on any help . We had a party of 8 . Was the worst service that we have ever experienced.

H5H-jQqQHuz9NOLm_frWeA.text: So very disappointed in this entire experience. The restaurant has terrible customer service and is unaccommodating and rude to their customers. After making a reservation and letting them know I would be late, they assured me that they would seat me if I arrived by 10pm. After walking around Caesar's Palace for 10 minutes, I called to let them know I had been unable to find the location and had been redirected by multiple employees to the wrong area of the hotel. I called to let them know I was lost at 10:01pm and the hostess put me on hold to ask the manager if they would seat us once we found the restaurant, as she stated had been done before. I was hung up on and when I called back she told me the manager would not accommodate us and would turn us away if we arrived.   I am extremely disappointed in this experience and urge anyone with good taste in restaurants to avoid this establishment that treats their customers with such disrespect and disregard. Shame on you, Raos.

Q1Y3JeuhqZEGTl_WFN3iBQ.text: Tough to arrive at a rating for Rao's.  Several things were done really well, some things were done okay, one thing was really bad, and the service wasn't great.  But, overall it was more good (or very good) than bad, so here we arrive at a 4 star rating.  We had reservations for 8 on a Friday.  We arrived promptly and only had to wait a couple of minutes while they set our table up.  We didn't love the placement of our table, it was like it was put in the middle of a dining room as an afterthought.  Not much room to maneuver, and other tables were all on top of us, so we asked to move and were accommodated.  The server brought us water and a wine list.  The wine list is above average for the Strip, and the prices are what you'd expect to pay.  Appropriately, there were several Italian wines on the list.  The somm was great, he came over and offered some assistance and was very friendly.  The bread service is good, it's served with 3 types of butter.  My favorite was the red pepper.  To start, we had 2 appetizers (baked clams and bruschetta) and two pastas (linguine with white claim sauce and rigatoni filletto).  The appetizers were average, probably one of the least impressive parts of the meal.  The baked clams were mostly bread crumbs, and they were over-salted.  They did have a nice crust on top from the broiler.  The bruschetta was good and fresh, but I could have used more balsamic. It was very basic.   Of the pastas, the linguine was vastly superior.  It was loaded with clams and the white wine sauce was great.  Cooked perfectly as well.  I considered ordering another order of this as a side dish, it was that good.  The rigatoni was too far on the other spectrum of al dente for me.  It had way too much bite.  And, the sauce didn't have the flavors we expected from the menu description:  pancetta, white onion, tomatoes, pecorino romano.  It tasted like a basic tomato sauce, I didn't get any taste of pancetta.  Had the pasta been cooked maybe a minute longer it would have been much better, but I wouldn't get this again.  For my entree, I ordered the veal parm.  But, our group is big on sharing dishes, so I also tried Uncle Vincent's lemon chicken, this chicken dish with peppers and sausage, and the pasta special of the evening, which was lobster and shrimp in a fra diavolo sauce.  We also got an order of meatballs to share.  As many Yelpers note, the meatballs are massive, softball size.  So, 2 of them was plenty for a group of 4, we each probably had nearly a half-pound of meatball to eat.  The entrees, in my order of preference:  veal parm, chicken with sausage and peppers, Uncle Vincent's, and the seafood pasta.  The veal chop is huge, thin, and breaded well.  You really don't need a knife, I cut it with my fork at least half the time.  It's covered in marinara and cheese.  It certainly isn't re-inventing the wheel, but it's a fantastic version of a classic dish.  The table loved it.  The chicken and peppers was good, with both being cooked well.  But, the star was the sausage.  Some of the best Italian sausage I can remember having, and it wasn't overcooked, so it retained some juiciness.  I can see why Uncle Vincent's is popular.  The chicken is prepared very well and is juicy.  I'm just not a huge lemon chicken guy, so the dish was lost on me.  But, I was glad to try one of Rao's more famous (which is saying something) dishes.  The fra diavolo was a miss.  It had no heat at all.  It was a watery tomato sauce with the seafood.  They would have been way better off just using the house marinara.  Very disappointing.  The guy that ordered it picked out all the seafood and then supplemented his dinner with stuff from our plates.    The meatballs have earned their reputation.  They are tender, moist, and very flavorful.  Just incredible.  Nothing more needs to be said that hasn't been said in decades about these things.  Just order them when you go, even if you just have a couple of bites.  Like I said, service was spotty.  At one point, we counted during an hour and we saw the somm more than we saw our server.  The restaurant was busy, but I am guessing that a place like Rao's is always busy.  That being said, for the most part the food was very good, and I would eat here again.

Photo of Rao's - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Rigatoni filetto di pomodoro.

XKC_45GJBz5u4PtITlUEFQ.text: I had dinner here on Tuesday, and enjoyed it a lot. We started with the seafood salad and the meatballs. The meatballs are always excellent, and quite big. The seafood salad was also good. I had the lamb chops and someone else had the vincents lemon chicken. The Lamb chops were cooked as ordered, but a bit small. The chicken was excellent. I have been here before and would come back.

9TtntKHYFYoh1sGmSPXCNA.text: Great food and atmosphere.  Rao was great! Second time coming here and so happy I came back.

0EfbSLqVgnbWcfOOKVZK8g.text: Thanks For Making My Birthday Special ! Delicsious Food And Great Peeps ! Thankful ..Blessed ..Blessings.. Xo

QV9DGDum1FxZBzTHRPr5_w.text: I had the scarpetto which was amazing. My wife ordered a side of rigatoni w/ Marinara and it was undercooked and stuck in one lump to the plate. I would have sent it back at Applebee's and that is an unforgivable sin for Italian fine dining. We started with the calamari which was amazing and the Cesar salad was also very good but for the price it didn't meet our expectations. The service was good but not great.

8O4nkfB9ZSpAVCLXOgB5rw.text: Dined at the bar on a Sunday night. Bar was empty with 3 bartenders working. Worst service I have ever experienced. I had to ask for water, water to be refilled, cheese for my entree, my check. Food  was average at best. Much better Italian options in Las Vegas.

h3XnDetWK-6ASSVEPLhZKw.text: Ate here with some coworkers and it was the worst experience I've had at a food establishment in a nice hotel. Myself and some coworkers were here for a conference and came here to eat on our last night and was given some gift cards to expense our meals. We asked the waiter Howard if he could do separate checks since we are traveling on business. Howard straight up said, "No because I always get shorted." I've worked in the food industry and all of the people I was with are managers in the customer service industry so we know how to tip. He said he could run our cards separately but would not split the check. We then had to figure out what each person had and write down the amount for him to run on each card. As we are figuring everything out, Howard starts talking about us to the manager (a female), then another waiter or buss boy walked to him and they both were talking about our table because I saw Howard point to our table. Then another worker walks towards them and he starts telling them about us too. Working in the customer service industry everything is about the customers perception and he should have taken his conversation out of our view.   The food wasn't great either so it's not like that was going to save this rating. The pasta that had seafood in it was extremely fishy. If I could give negative stars, I would.   I would recommend going to Trevi at the forum shops, the food and service is excellent there!

XMYkB4IS3f53yjo2t3iXDA.text: I am a HUGE foodie. All I can say about this place is AMAZING. Rebecca Rebecca Rebecca. She was so helpful and knowledgeable about the menu. She made choosing an item so much easier. Great service. Great food. When we make it back to Vegas again, we will definitely be eating here and asking that Rebecca be our server. Best meal in Vegas!!!

EQJX9Eyfz7zjxopQEZUj2Q.text: Rao's was very disappointing. We went here to celebrate a birthday and to say the service was terrible is an understatement. We both got pasta dishes and although those were OK, the lack of service put a cloud over the rest of the night. We arrive and our waiter didn't come for a quite a while. When he did come, he didn't bring a wine list.We had to ask for a wine with because we'd like to order wine with our Italian dishes. Took him a while to come back to get our orders and food came really quickly. With all of the different restaurants in Vegas, I'm disappointed that we chose this time

RniWgt4Xcgps0CPN-w5ycw.text: Stopped in to pick up an order of Meatballs to go on a Monday night. I arrived about 9:15. The hostess told me that the kitchen closed early at 9 for summer hours despite the fact that their website said 10 p.m.  Rebecca, one of the servers, overheard that and said that she would see if she could put a special order in for me. A few minutes later Rebecca came around the corner with my to go order. The meatballs were cooked to perfection but more importantly this was a great example of exceptional service! Thanks so much Rebecca!

NuXycSlY6wHetkuFj645ng.text: Wanted to check out this Italian place and compare to Carbone.  Order the meatballs, penne vodka, seafood di mare and lobster croquette. meatballs came out pretty fast but the rest of the food took a long time to come out . Meatballs and the sauce was salty to my liking, penne vodka was pretty good, didn't really like the seafood di mare, seafood wasn't fresh. Overall experience was jus ok. If I had to choose between this place and Carbone, hands down Carbone!! This is jus my opinion. Meatballs at Carbone is better and their sauce over the meatballs were not salty.

h8Jvgt6ddnuHpXTIGcaWyA.text: We WERE long time customers of Rao's, dining there each time we were in Las Vegas. This past January we dined there with another couple. Later that night, the two husbands got violently sick, almost to the point on being incapacitated. We had eaten the same food all day, except the husbands ate Rao's meatballs at dinner. That is not why I am writing this review. In the restaurant business, stuff happens   The next day we called Rao's to let them know what had happened. We weren't looking for anything. We thought they should know. We gave all of our information to the manager. She told us that someone from their Risk Management Dept. would call us. NEVER HAPPENED! She also told us that after they investigated someone would follow up with us. NEVER HAPPENED!  The lack of concern, compassion and communication was astounding. This was not about bad meatballs! It is about basic customer service. We will never go there again. Oh, thats right, Rao's doesn't care!

Ub8zECEsxPieozZ2SJ-2ZQ.text: Was so disappointed! Heard such good things ! Went there .. service was awful and food was below average :( atmosphere was nice but not a great vibe when almost empty on a holiday ;( bummer !

q7FY8N9dQHTF3pbs_VTicA.text: My rating is based on two visits.   I was beyond disappointed with Rao's during my first visit. When we walked in, the hostess asked "how can I help you??" without looking up from her computer, with a less than friendly tone. During my second visit, the hostess was way better but still not inviting. The first person you see in a restaurant really sets the tone.   First visit- We ordered chicken parmigiana to share. The bartender said it was a big portion and it would be enough to share but it wasn't. $44 for a single portion, that wasn't anything special.   Second visit- We started with the meatballs ($19) and they were delicious! The waitress said they were a must have and I see why! I ordered the lasagna ($32) this time and it was a good size portion and yummy! Also, the bread is amazing! I was afraid I was going to be full before the food came out lol!

tp9ndzigRsk9EXFcoTnzFA.text: Worst veal Marsala I've ever had. The sauce was like Salisbury steak sauce. Not representative of Italian food from New York.  Service was good.

Wxyj84Aj_MHz-9xEWoe5yA.text: Ordered the Eggplant Parmesan for $31. It came out as 5 slices of bitter eggplant covered in cheese and a tiny bit of sauce. Terribly disappointing.

CQIVQeTBRGZELJRT-OxAzA.text: Rao's is Rao's is Rao's is Rao's.   From the first time I stepped foot in Rao's in NYC and ate their meatballs I have been obsessed with the sauce, the simplicity and the history.   The Las Vegas Rao's is not the same as walking into the Harlem Rao's in NYC and why would you want it to be! You can't recreate an original, but you can stir up a feeling, an energy and an atmosphere - this is what Las Vegas does.   Everything is bigger in Vegas - including Rao's! Walking through Ceasar's Palace you can't miss Rao's. The iconic red corner restaurant greets you past the slot machines. While I did not make a reservation I would suggest you do so if you are trying to make a show or go during prime dinner/lunch service.  I chose to eat at the bar since I was solo. After taking my seat and ordering wine, I remembered the late Frankie Pellegrino telling me there was a recreation of the NYC Rao's in Vegas and asked the bartender which room it was - sure enough there it was! It is pretty spot on with the exception of the bar is missing and the regulars are still in NYC - look up the history of this restaurant you won't be disappointed.   I returned to my seat at the bar placed my order and the servers started their cadence - wine came out, placemat, silverware, bread basket w/gourmet butters and my napkin - if you want full service come here!  Shortly after diving into the bread basket my ravioli followed from the kitchen. The portion was well worth the price and I was full all day! If I wasn't in the midst of conversation (and in a public place) I would have licked the bowl.   The menu is pricey so keep this in mind, but it is delicious and will not disappoint. You are paying for an experience that many people will not ever have - while it is not as exclusive as NYC it is still an extension of Rao's, an extension of the family. Enjoy!

KIUepKbl6FBQNm_5iYhXBA.text: A friend of mine has been raving about Rao's authentic Italian cuisine especially the "infamous" meatballs.  I'm following a Pescatarian friendly diet so I had to pass on the meatballs but my friend girl ordered them and not only did they smell good but they looked amazing as well!   DINNER RESERVATIONS HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!! This place is very busy!  I ordered:  *ANTIPASTI Fritto Misto (fried calamari, cod fish, shrimp and zucchini) $24 I was a little hesitant about this mix but it exceeded my expectations. The shrimp are gigantic and the calamari was fried perfectly. Sharing recommended because it's a great portion size.  *PRIMI Spinach & Ricotta Ravioli $30 These ravioli are a great vegetarian entree. The Ravioli were pretty large and equally delicious.   *Bottle of Pinot Grigio $60  *The meatballs are huge and my friend enjoyed them greatly $19   I would definitely return in the near future

Not savory at all.  Good with white wine.   Happy hour is 5-7 now.   Check it out. It's just drinks on the hh menu

TZgDbGLHYK47XgG3NJAhCA.text: We haven't been at Rao's for almost 10 years and the last time it left us under whelmed. Tonight was superb. We had the a Sangiovese wine from Tuscany, I had the veal chop and my husband had the chicken Scarpariella. The waiter recommended an angel hair pasta wit it that was perfect pair.  We finished dinner with a Tiramisu that was perfect. Dinner was heavenly.

TxXvzDVoJzS0Eunk2nG_5g.text: My husband and I don't vacation as much since we are new parents. We came to vegas and decided to splurge on a nice dinner...Oh Em Gee the food was so amazing! The biggest steak they make is enough for a table of 4. It was amazing from the service to the ambiance and definitely the food!  We will be back!

GTXA0xyI4IlhatcT0WM7gA.text: Had dinner at Raos Saturday night.  This is my third time there.  Hoping it would get better.  Had the pounded veal chop which tasted old.  Baked clams and  fried sea food appetizer.  The food at this very expensive restaurant was just average.  Absolutely not worth the $350.00 the check came to for 2 people.  Way, way overrated and overpriced  for mediocre Italian food. Many far better options on or near the strip for significantly less money. I wont be back. Mike S. Henderson

zfyk_H-4oaiGTZyRWuLhcg.text: This place was so bad. I'm really disappointed that we wasted our money.  We were staying at Caeser's Palace and didn't want to step outside of the hotel that night, and RAO's was recommended to us by the hotel staff. They spoke really highly about the meatballs. I like a good meatball and that's usually hard to mess up. Heck, I even like frozen meatballs from the grocery. So, we order the meatballs which was $20 for two meatballs (eye roll). I'm going to try really hard to find the positive. It was airy. The negative? Of course, the price but that would've been okay if it was actually good. Instead, it was flavorless. I tried really hard to finish it because even the server was going on and on about how amazing their meatballs were. I couldn't finish it though. It tasted like water. Basically, it tasted like nothing. Next came a beef lasagna but it was whatever. Just a regular beef lasagna which was also too pricey at $36, I think? We couldn't finish that either, not because it was huge but because it was just average. You can get better quality at my local Italian diner where I live, and it's less than half of the price at RAO's. The servers were friendly. The greeting staff had some attitude which they should work on because honestly, for the food they serve, I'm surprised they have an attitude. Every other restaurant we ate at on the strip were wonderful (see my other reviews from Vegas for suggestions). Save your money and you can eat at least 2 great meals for the same price elsewhere. So, feel free to give this place a miss.

ZZXQuKPH6dP0EkXQOv8TZw.text: Best Italian food in Vegas! No contest. Great atmosphere. Excellent service. The food is utterly out of this world! Just the spaghetti and meatballs will keep you coming back for more. No. They'll keep you LONGING for it!!! Seriously. Try this place you won't regret it.

BCIBlHCV6DKlxkG7jq9vJQ.text: Got on few hours ago. Staying at Ceasars so this was a quick convenience. Not too crowded after all its the day before thanksgiving.  Menu fairly decent selection. Prices moderate to high . Does not look or feel very Italian. I guess it's supposed to be a New York storefront family style. See photo. My flat steak $40 a la carte. Moderate. Seems a little mall-like.  Staff not too enthusiastic . Our waiter was ok. Maybe with thanksgiving tomorrow there is a desire to go home! I've eaten all over the world and take my reviews very seriously. So, would I eat here again? I would not go out of my way or tell someone to eat here but would if convenient. 3.5*

1rfjlRyaLzgz_1hqA3Qqng.text: Sad to say that I'm a little disappointed by the dining experience I just had at Rao's.  I first went to Rao's over 5 years ago and had one of the best meals ever....I've been back since then MANY times and I feel like it's on a slow decline.  We were a table of 8 tonight and although the service was amazing...the food was just ok.  3 people at the table ordered the eggplant parm dish (used to be one of my favorite dishes at Rao's)...it came under cooked, grilled and topped with arugula. I'm sorry but eggplant parm needs to be breaded and fried!  What's weird is that I was here maybe two months ago and the eggplant was definitely breaded and fried...lacking flavor but still at least it was cooked how it should be.  They must have changed the recipe but not for the better. My other issue is how can they possibly charge $44 for a small piece of chicken parm and spaghetti!?!?! If I'm paying $44 for chicken parm, it better be the size of my dinner plate and the best thing I've ever tasted.  I know I'm in Vegas but come on...that's just ridiculous! Unfortunately my coworkers weren't really thrilled with there dinners either...saying that "this is just something I can make at home." However, I am happy to report that their meatballs are still melt in your mouth good! They are the one thing they still have going for them. I really hope next time I'm in Vegas they try some new recipes and fix the eggplant parm!

sluF-y2UQgF3h4iThPqZZQ.text: Serving old school traditional Italian faire nestled in the middle of Caesar's Palace, Rao's is worthy of a special occasion dinner.    The long and storied history of the restaurant is  depicted in the hundreds of photographs of the owner and satisfied celebrities and dignitaries  who have visited one of their locations over the decades they have been in business.  If you enjoy celebrating Christmas year round, the holly, lights, and ornaments strewn across the bar and ceiling will have you humming Jingle Bells.    We really enjoyed the lasagna and penne vodka.  The bolognese and pink sauces made the dishes exceptional.  The crusty, yet soft in the middle Italian  bread, was fresh and tasty.   You won't leave the place hungry.  The portions are generous.      Bravo Rao's !!

_yPJVdNR65mSQnZVywa5aQ.text: The food is always amazing here! Russ was a fantastic waiter and completely turned our night around (we had tickets to Rod Stewart tonight but found out night of the show had been cancelled). We drowned our heartbreak in carbs and I regret nothing!   Highly recommend the spaghetti bolognese and add a meatball! Portion is plenty filling for two to share :).

kSC7bPCiP2lubLIRpmbvzA.text: Service was not good. Food took a long time, and was decent at best.

jG7AMChJr-h-kBVk2XhLMg.text: Living in Philly, I've never felt robbed of a proper Italian meal, thanks to the bevy of South Philly offerings and all that is Marc Vetri's pastas. But when I'm told I'm unable to gain admittance to one of NYC's stalwart Italian restaurants, I can't help but feel the need to sneak my way in. The original NYC Rao's has a 100+ year history in East Harlem and is a celebrity-laden experience that reserves tables for "members." So unless you're a "friend of a friend" as they say, you ain't getting in.  So what recourse does a regular Joe or Jane have? Take a flight to Vegas and stop by the Rao's at Caesar's Palace! The menu is virtually the same along with an attempt to provide the same "in the know" experience. It's also replete with snarky, but experienced servers - a classic old school Italian touch.  Bread Service  You start off with Italian bread, which wasn't served warm, but was plenty fresh. A nice spread of red pepper ricotta and olive oil spread came in place of just your typical EVOO.  Mozzarella Carrozza [$16 / $15 Total Rewards]  The fried mozzarella was smaller than they may appear, especially if you consider that each triangle was $8. Enough for four decent bites in sum. Still, they were perfectly and crisply fried, housing undeniably fresh mozzarella within. A pat of simply sweet and slightly tangy marinara accompanied the mozzarella.  Taglioline with Peas & Ham [$30 / $29 Total Rewards]  Fresh made pasta, prosciutto cotto, sweet peas, light Parmesan cream sauce   The GF went with the taglioline pasta, which was nicely al dente and fresh. The light Parmesan cream sauce was sweeter than expected, with what seemed to be the essence of corn. The cooked prosciutto provided light heft to each bite, though I think pancetta may have been better served to counter the sweetness of the peas. Still, it helped to make each bite not overly heavy for a cream-based pasta dish.   Uncle Vincent's Lemon Chicken [$30 / $29 Total Rewards]  Charcoal broiled, bone-in chicken, Uncle Vincent's famous lemon sauce   I went with the famed lemon chicken, which featured wonderfully crisp skin and a juicy, moist bird. Keep in mind, there are plenty of bones to pick through with this dish, but hey - that's where the flavor is right? The lemon cannot be denied - sharp and bright.  Traditional Rao's Meatballs [$18 / $17 Total Rewards]  Ground veal, pork, beef, Italian bread crumbs, marinara   You'd be best served by trying their meatballs. In contrast with the fried mozzarella, these were huge. So big in fact that our party of five went with two orders, but one would have sufficed (that's with the belly of this pig in tow). Extremely moist and well-seasoned, there was also a great char developed on the exterior. Wonderful.   We were actually in Vegas to celebrate the GF's brother's 21st, so our server, Russ, brought out complimentary tiramisu (light, with great coffee essence), along with his kazoo. A nice touch.  I'm pretty sure the fuss for the Rao's in NYC is more about the exclusivity factor. Sure, the dishes are very good, but there are plenty of great Italian options in the city without having to jump through hoops. That being said, I can see why members would return. So if you're craving quality Italian while in Vegas, I would definitely give the Caesar's outpost a try.

ndJjsTncNxlrBUwB_eT8Ww.text: Meatballs was good, but smaller than the ones on Los Angeles. Spaghetti was undercooked and chewy. I told the waiter if i wore dentures they would pull them right out. They comped us on the cappuccino though.

9yk5kl5NbKJ7VJ2cJkLSeg.text: Generally unamused by Restaurant Week, an excuse for infrequent diners to eat dumbed-down menus from restaurant's they'd not normally visit in the name of a charity that would be better served by direct donations, it was only long-standing New York Import Rao's at Caesars Palace that seemed willing to do something interesting with the $50.15 prix-fixe, a selection of novelties offered in addition to the restaurant's fabled fare finally providing a reason to check the space off a long-term list of places as-yet unseen.  Currently toqued by Chef Fatimah Madyun with pastry duties assigned to Laura Augsburger, Rao's Las Vegas was the second amongst three current iterations of the East Harlem classic whose 'impossible' reservations and 'owned' tables garner far more attention than the food, yet with the Southern Italian recipes of Frank Pellegino presented True to form  the menu itself is a well-culled pick em' of  plates to please any palate, the "On-Strip" pricing and stereotyped Eye-talian service an expected footnote probably best ignored.  Dining as a group of five, and as such able to sample widely from a tasting served in four family-style courses despite initial suggestions that the Restaurant Week option could not be 'added' to a larger scale meal, it was in a basket of fresh bread in three varieties paired to peppery tomato cream that the meal began and as much as restraint was attempted given all the upcoming carbs, any resistance proved futile as the warm trio was replenished more than once - the bites not topped with creamy spread proving more than amenable to sopping up any sauce gone astray.  Dividing the meal into appetizers, pastas, entrees, and dessert, with a bit of overlap to balance out courses two and three, it was after a short delay that round one was delivered along with glasses of wine for those choosing to imbibe, and although the well seasoned clams proved somewhat skimpy in portion given the pricetag there is little argument that Rao's signature meatballs more than justify their legendary status, the balance of meat and breadcrumbs somehow dense and dainty at the same time with a spice profile that melded well to both crushed San Marzanos as well as the special cream sauce rife with blue cheese.  Noting that the large space was perhaps 2/3 full throughout much of the stay, and that waiters appeared stretched across sections that saw them working two-tiers of the restaurant at once, there was again a sizable delay paired to empty glasses prior to pastas presented by a pair of back-servers, yet when the three piping hot plates arrived almost all sins were immediately forgiven, the imported dry bucatini prepared perfectly al dente beneath a smooth lacquer of eggs, pork, and cream while the tubes of Rigatoni were equally well textured amidst an aromatic red sauce, the housemade purses a far more mild option that may have benefitted from a bit of salt or grated Pecorino, though the bites taken with dried cranberries were admittedly quite nice.  Seeing secondi arrive in a much more expedited manner than the prior course, each dish served with an appropriate warning that plates were 'extremely hot,' it was here that the Restaurant Week special of Duck Cannelloni was presented and although the composition was perhaps a bit reminiscent of the aforementioned ravioli the utilization of confit duck proved a substantial upgrade to the milky ricotta in terms of both taste and texture, the $51 Veal Parmesan a bit overpriced despite good quality and substantial portion while the lemon chicken was moist and surprisingly restrained, the crispy charred skin proving a more than admirable foil to the citrus.  Already selecting a single cannoli as part of the prix fixe, and adding on a $32 platter with three more options to share, dessert at Rao's no doubt trends towards the classics and as good as both the dense cheesecake and crisp tube of lightly lemon cream were, neither could outmatch the block of espresso-soaked ladyfingers amidst mascarpone, let alone the peanut butter tart that no-doubt tipped its hat to Reese's while simultaneously meeting the tongue both rich and as light as a cloud.  While some purists may suggest that such 'one-off' concepts are disingenuous to the original others may consider such things to be a benefit providing the cooking is on point, particularly since most lack the political (or mob) ties required to visit the original and would likely be better served eating somewhere else in The Big Apple instead.  Setting aside high prices and service that would benefit from a few more hands-on-deck, Rao's is a worthy dinner for those seeking rustic red sauce on the Strip.
